editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it is ACTED BY HIS Majeſties Servants.
LONDON, Printed for R. Bently in Covent-Garden, and Joſeph-Hindmarſh, Book-Seller to His Royal Highneſs. M.DC.LXXXIII.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
THis PLAY, ſince its comming to light, has ſo clear'd its Self and Me from Aſperſions, that I am 〈◊〉 what I ſhall now, will appear Vanity, and a flouriſhing the Colours after Victory; but I think it not prudent to lay down Arms, when there is an Enemy in the Field: ſeveral Stories that once wounded my Reputation, and half ſmother'd this Play, ſtill March up and down and do me private Miſchief, and every Day they get new Detachments of additional Inventions; ſome of theſe I think my ſelf bound to deal withal. 'Tis ſaid, I openly confeſt, who I meant by the principal Characters in the Play, particularly by that of Bartoline. That this is falſe, common ſence, and the Character it ſelf will prove. Is it poſſible, I ſhou'd be ſuch a Bartholomew-Cokes, to pull out my Purſe in a Fair, and as ſoon as ever a Knave tickled my Ear with a Sraw (a little ſilly Flattery) I ſhou'd let go my Diſcretion and perhaps my Fortune? (for Libels may prove coſtly things.) They that made this Fool's Coat for me, ſhou'd firſt have been ſure it wou'd fit me, leaſt it be turn'd on their Hands, and they made to wear it themſelves. 'Tis known, I am too guilty of the other, extream of Reſerv'dneſs, I do not often expoſe my Writings, much leſs my Thoughts naked; And for the ſame reaſon that Beggars keep out of the way, when they find the Officers ſevere, the Overſeers of the Folly of the Pariſh, have ſo often Whipt an undreſt poor piece of mine round the Town, when I brought it to beg a little Charitable Covering, that I care not to come at 'em. If I had nothing to d •
pend on, but the Collections of Wit in the Play-Wardens-Box, I ſhou'd be miſerable. If therefore I find ſuch ill Entertainment, from thoſe who pretend to provide for us, cou'd I hope for good from Strangers and Enemies? In the next place, is it probable, I ſhou'd make my ſelf worſe then I am, and accuſe my ſelf of Miſchief I never intended? That I never deſign'd to perſona • e any one, appears, becauſe I have not done it; for I who have drawn
the general Corruption of Lawyers ſo well, as to pleaſe conſiderable Judges, indeed the whole Town, cou'd with as much eaſe have Pictur'd any Mans particular qualities, which I wou'd not hear of, though ſome would have entic'd me to it. That I have made my Lawyer old and Married to a young Wife, is of no more concernment to any Gentleman in thoſe Circumſtances, then the deſcription of a Thief in a Gazette, by his Wigg and Coat, is to an Honeſt Man directly ſo habited; He that finding his Friend • Acco •• rements agree in ſome thing with thoſe in the Advertiſement, ſhall think him a Thief, and draw his Sword to defend him from every Conſtable, deſerves to be laugh'd at for an Aſs. I had a more honourable Opinion of thoſe who are ſaid to be perſonated, then to ſuſpect any one, wou'd Apprehend them by Two ſuch Lewd Characters as Barroline and Lucinda; to which they are ſo directly oppoſite in all things, but what is innocent and common, Age and Marriage. If I muſt have ſtript my Characters of theſe for fear of giving offence, I muſt not bring'd Villain on the Stage with a Noſe, becauſe many honeſt Men have Noſes, and ſome of 'em may be thought to be aim'd at. Nor is any one old Man, more than another, mimiqued by Mr. Lee's way of ſpeaking, which all the Comedians can witneſs was my own invention, and Mr. Lee was taught it by me; to prove this farther, I have Printed Bartoline's part in that manner of ſpelling, by which I taught it Mr. Lee. They who have no Teeth cannot pronounce many Letters plain, but perpetually liſp, and break their words; and ſome words they cannot bring out at all. As for inſtance; th, is pronounc'd by thruſting the Tongue hard to the Teeth, therefore that ſound they cannot make, but ſomething like it. For that reaſon you will often find in Bartoline's part, inſtead of th, a y, as yat for that, yiſh for this, yoſh for thoſe, ſometimes a t is left out, as houſhand for thouſand, hirchy for thirty; ſ▪ they pronounce like ſh, as Sher for Sir, muſht for muſt; t, they ſpeak like ch; therefore you will find, chrue for true, Chreaſon for Treaſon, cho for to, choo for two, chen for ten, chake for take. And this ch is not to be pronounc'd like k, as 'tis in Christian but as in Child, Church, Cheſt. I deſire the Reader to obſerve theſe things, becauſe otherwiſe he will hardly underſtand much of the Lawyers part, which in the opinion of all is the moſt divertiſing in the Comedy; but when this ridiculous way of ſpelling is familiar with him, it will render the part more pleaſant.

The next ſuſpitious Character is that of the Doctor; ſome ſay I have abus'd an Eminent Divine to whom this Nation is much oblieg'd, and are greatly offended: Either that Divine is guilty of the faults I have expos'd, or not; if he be not, they abuſe him by applying them to him; if he be, he is not wrong'd at all. If a Divine's Coat be foul, is it Sacriledge to bruſh it, and make him fit for Chriſtian Society? ſtrangely preposterous is the zeal of ſome Men, they will burn the Picture of Chriſt wherever they find it, but defend the Picture of the Devil if it be in the poſſeſſion of one of their Friends. And St. Jude tells us, A Railer and Deſpiſer of Dignities, is not like a good Angel, for St. Michael wou'd not rayl at the Devil; but I charge no Man with theſe Crimes, they who have a mind to beſtow 'em on their Friends may. The other Characters I ſhall not trouble my ſelf withal, but leave 'em to be ſhar'd among the Party as they pleaſe.

Having thus vindicated my Innocence, I muſt ſay ſomething in behalf of my Diſcretion. Suppoſe I have not injur'd particulars, yet in aſſaulting a whole powerful Party, I appear little leſs than a Mad Man, at least in their opinion; perhaps I was ſo, when I firſt wrote this Play, then half the Nation was mad, and no Man that I ſaw had cauſe to be ſo but the Poets; our Trades and Lib •• ties were actually ſei • 'd; all Profeſſions broke in upon us, and made themſelves Free of the Company of Rhimers, without any Charter from Nature. • ews-Mongers and Intelligencers took up the invention of Fables, and ſo clog'd the Market ours wou'd not vend. Joyners, Carpenters, and Bricklayers, applyed themſelves to the building of State-Projects, and in order to that, very often took meaſure of Verſe, but none o' their own heads, which they 〈◊〉 have found very unfit for either Profeſſion, of Poetry or Policy. 〈◊〉 it is hard the Authours of theſe Confuſions ſhou'd upbraid us with a Diſtemper themſelves occaſion'd, nay, encourag'd in their Friends, whom they endeavour'd to make as Mad as they cou'd; and truly when I ſaw ſo many Mad Men, I thought it a Shame for a Poet not to be as Mad as any one elſe. Tameneſs in a Poet is as great a Diſeaſe as • renzy in another, and when a Poet does not rave, his Wits are not right. When all Mens brains were a Galloping, I cou'd not hold in mine, and I play'd but the ſame • reaks others did; they rede a tilt at Lawful, and I at unlawful Powers; Mechaniques leapt over the Heads of Princes, and I over the Heads of Mechaniques; and I was
held in ſo long, till they were taken many holes lower, that now I may be accounted a very ſober Rider, and neither my Neck nor Diſcretion in danger. I am threatned by a Parliament, but they have a Childiſh opinion of that wiſe Aſſembly, who think they will concern themſelves for ſuch Poppets as I have made ſport with. No doubt they will endeavour to tune the Nation, but not with ſuch clattering Keys as mine; they will maintain the Laws, but not the Knavery and corruption of Lawyers; they will defend the Liberties of the Subject, but rayling, faction and ſawcineſs, are no part of our Liberties that I know of; they will encourage the Evidences of the late Popiſh Plot againſt our Religion, but neither them or others in a Plot againſt good Manners. No doubt 'tis hateful to ſee Popes tread on the Necks of Princes, but 'tis as odious to ſee a Rabble fling dirt in their Faces: they will ſuppreſs the enemies of our Religion and Government, than they will encourage this Comedy, for it promotes the ſame deſign. Any one that knows the dialect of theſe times, muſt needs underſtand the true Proteſtants reflected on in this Comedy, are a ſort of Men who abuſe that Honourable name by taking it to themſelves; and whilſt they cry Proteſtant Religion. Proteſtant Religion, mean as much another thing, as the Chimneyſwe • per did that cry'd Mull'd-Sack. A ſturdy crue they are, that think to de • ie all Authority, and obtain what ever they ask, by beging in numbers like Gypſies. They pretend alſo to Fortune-telling, and exactly to know what ſhall be any Mans Deſtiny at the Conjunction of ſuch Heavenly Bodies as a Parliament; or it may be by Phiſiognomy, if your Eyes be not as good in ſeeing Plots as theirs, and by twenty other marks in the Face or Hand: but they are ſo often miſtaken in their predictions, their Art is become ridiculous. The Lines in my hand I do not underſtand, but I do perfectly thoſe in my Comedy, and I am certain by them to ſuffer no miſchief from good Men; I may as I have done already, from Lyars and barbarous cowardly Aſſaſſinates. Thus much for the Innocence and Honeſty of my Self and the Play, the Wit and Poetry of it, I leave to ſhift for th • mſelves. I have heard nothing ſubſtantial objected againſt them, ſo I ſhall not fight with Chirmeras. They who cannot find any Wit in it, perhaps wou'd be as much at a loſs, if it were never ſo full, for 'tis probable Wit and they are ſo great Strangers, they may meet and never know it. They who do not like the Plot, muſt blame the Faction, who invented the Original, for mine's but a Coppy.

div.head: The Prologue,
div.l: GOOD Heaven be Thankt, the Frenzy of the Nation
Begins to Cure, and Wit to grow in Faſhion:
Long the Two Theatres did proudly jarr,
And for Chief Sway, like Two Republiques Warr;
When of the ſudden, a Devouring Hoſt
Of Dreadful Knights, (I ſay not of the Poſt)
But ſtrange Tongue Warriors, over-ran the Town,
And Bl • w the Stage, almoſt the Kingdome down.
And with the Stage the P • ets muſt expire,
For Bells will melt, if Steeples be on Fire;
Then Coffee-Houſes Th • atres were grown,
Where Zealots acted in a furious tone,
Oliver's Porter Damming Babylon.
But they more Mad; for he in his worſt 〈◊〉 ,
Was ne'r ſo Mad as to Talk TREASON yet.
'Tis ſtrange thoſe Men ſhould wiſh the POPE ſuch Evil,
Who are ſo kind to the POPE's Friend, the DEVILS.
They Drink, they Whore, and at their Rulers Rant,
And all is well in a True PROTESTANT.
Theſe Follies have the Nation long Employ'd,
And almoſt all the POETS Trade deſtroy'd.
That they may juſtly ſeek Repriſals now,
And Board thoſe Pyrates which brought them ſo low;
Seize on that Ware, by which ſome Men by ſtealth
Promote the Traffick of a Common-Wealth▪
Ware, ſome believe by Prieſts and Jeſuits Spun,
They Weave the Cloath, FANATICKS put in on.
But ſome will ſay, a POET mend the Age!
In theſe High Matters how dare they engage?
Why, SIRS, a Poets Reformation ſcorn;
Since the Reformers now all POETS turn?
And by their awkard jangling Rhimes proclaim,
Like Bells rung backward, that the Town's on Flame:
The City WHIGGS ſuch curſed Poets chuſe,
For that alone they ſhould their CHARTER loſe.
He is a wretched Coxcomb, who believes
Muſes, like JƲRIES, will be packt by SHERIFFS.
But their ill Pallat no fine dreſſing needs,
All Stuff that any Whiggiſh Fancy breeds,
They ſwallow down, and live like Ducks on Weeds.
Theſe things give all the Nations round delight,
Sure at our Fools to laugh we have moſt right.
Lets not our Mirth to Forraign Kingdoms ſend,
But here the growth of our own Country ſpe • d.
Heaven knows what ſumms the CAƲSE has coſt this Town!
Here You may have it all for Half-a-Crown.

list.item: Florio. A Debauch, who pretends to be Dying of the Diſeaſes his Vices brought upon him, and penitent, in love with Roſaura.
Artali. A Debauch that follows the Court, in love with Lucinda.
Paulo Camillo. A Factious, proud, buſie, credulous, fooliſh, rich Citizen, choſen Chief Magiſtrate, or Lord Podeſta of Naples.
Craffy. His Son, an impudent, amorous, pragmatical Fopp, that pretends to Wit and Poetry, in love with his Fathers Wife.
A Bricklayer. A bold, ſawcy, Factious Fellow, that governs the Podeſta.
Doctor Panchy. An ignorant railing Fellow, that pretends to Learning.
The Governour of the City. A Man of Honour and Worth.

A fooliſh miſtaking Iriſ •
Witneſs Suborned by Bartoline.
Roſaura. A Wanton beautiful Woman, Married to the Podeſta, and in love with Florio.
Lucinda. An ignorant wanton Country Girl, Married to Bartoline.

sp.speaker: FLorio.
sp.p: Pietro.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What News Pietro? Has the worthy Citizen, whom I have Elected to be my Cuckold, attain'd the other Dignity of Podeſta of Naples yet?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Not yet Sir, but he will attain it very ſpeedily, all his Party are hard at work, Voices and Elboes at it, and they exceed the other Forty for one.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am glad of it Pietro for when he is chief Magiſtrate of Naples, I ſhall be—of his Wife, diſpatch his Domeſtick Affairs, and receive all the Fees of that ſweet Office.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: In troth you deſerve it Sir, for you buy the Place dear.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Indeed I give a great deal for it Pietro, I give ſome ſcores of ready Miſtreſſes I have in bank for the reverſion of one, which perhaps I may never enjoy.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: A great Price Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo Pietro, I give away a hundred other pleaſures into the bargain; as Drunkenneſs, a ſweet ſin Pietro, Wine is as neceſſary to a Man, as a Navigable River to a City, it conveys to him many pleaſant Commodities; without it, he muſt depend upon his own growth.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: 'Tis true Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then I part with all the ſociety of my witty lewd Friends, to keep company with dull lewd Saints.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Not Saints Sir, but Whigs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's as bad, and ſo looſe the Reputation of my Loyalty and good Affection to my Prince.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: You alſo part with the Reputation of being ſound Sir, and of your affection to Women: In ſhort Sir, you paſs for a poor, rotten dying Saint.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A dead Saint Pietro, at leaſt a dead Sinner, for I appear the Ghoſt of what I was, all my Vices mortified, and I am in a Wold very different from that I us'd to live in; I talk Godly, a ſtrange Language to me Pietro; I Pray, hear Sermons, live ſoberly, abſtain from Wine, Women, and Wits, a ſtrange life to me; but this new World is a diſmal Purgatory, for as yet I have not attain'd my Heaven! my Roſaura, if I ſhould never attain her Pietro—

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: • Twill not be her fault Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's true Pietro.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Sir ſhe is not frightned by the Ghoſt you appear to be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No Pietro, ſhe knows me to be Fleſh and Blood, ſound Fleſh and Blood, whoſe onely Diſeaſe is a troubleſome watchful Cuckold, if I can be cur'd of him, ſhe'l venture on me.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: If you never attain her Sir, Heaven be prais'd, you won't looſe your ſufferings, you will attain the States-man's Miſtris, Popularity.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Popularity! Dam her! a lewd, inconſtant, common Proſtitute; ſo old ſhe's blind, and cannot diſtinguiſh an honeſt Man from a Knave, though ſhe has a hundred pair of Spectacles put on her Noſe, that ſhew the Knave never ſo clear, ſhe crys I can't ſee him; Ignoramus, Ignora
• us, that's all the ſence ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: It may be not Sir, ſhe ſees well enough, but is too cunning to lay open the blemiſhes of her Stallion.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but were ſhe fairer then the moſt doting old Stateſman thinks her, ſhe is not ſo charming as a Hundred beautiful Women which I looſe for her.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: That's true Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do not the Ladies give me for gone?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: For a Dead Man Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And do they lament me?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: All, all, Sir, the vertuous Ladies ſigh, and cry 'tis pitty, the other run diſtracted, the very common Whores abſtain from Plays, and Bawds neglect their Brandy-Bottles.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You ſee what it is, Pietro, to do good in a Mans Generation; Hark!
sp.stage: A Shout, Paulo, Paulo, Pietro goes out, and preſently re-enters.
sp.p: The News Pietro?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Your Friend is Choſen Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is he? then ſhall I enter into my Employment ſpeedily; now he is fill'd with Authority, he will be drunk with Pride to th'end of his Year, and I can make him reel whether and when I pleaſe; Hark! ſomebody comes—

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Eſquire Artall Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That Rogue! my Patch upon my Noſe, my Pillow and ſick Equipage quickly.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Where's this damn'd confounded Hypocrite? this religious, ſactious, dying Saint? I come to give you Thanks for the Legacy you leave the Nation, a ſweet Rogue you have helpt into power; we ſhall have a ſine time on't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sir, if I have committed any crime in't, let the Law puniſh me, but do not Murder me with all this noiſe, I have mortal diſtempers enough upon me, I need not your bawling.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That you have not one ſound part in your Soul or Body I • irmly believe; that the greateſt part of your Body comes out of Shops, and every night goes not into Bed but Boxes, I know; but that your Soul and Body, although they have uſed one another, are upon parting, I no more believe, then that your Soul and your Vices are parted.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I value not what you believe Sir, but why ſhou'd it be incredible a Man ſhou'd part with any thing that uſes him ill? ſay my Vices had not Murder'd me, 'tis ſufficient they fool'd and enſlav'd me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ah poor Man!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I was a common Belman with my Rhimes to chime Fools aſleep in their Sins, a Beadle to Whip out of the Pariſh impudent Beggers, and ſuch we eſteem all Church-Creeds and Principles.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: So you do ſtill Sir, and are as little Charitable to 'em, whatever you pretend, as to any other kind of Beggers, for you will give good words to any handſome Begger you hope to make a Whore of; And you have a worſe deſign on Religion, to make her a Bawd to carry on ſome lewd project.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Rail on, or Laugh on, or both, I care not, you and the reſt of my Atheiſtical Companions were Heaven-threat'ning, which ſtood long between me and the Church; and though I dwelt among you, I confeſs, to my ſhame, I was afraid of you; but now (Heaven be praiſed) I have travel'd beyond you, and ſhall never look back on thoſe horrors and precipices more.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And are now got within a Days Journey of Heaven; Are you not Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is that to you Sir? get you about your buſineſs, do not diſturb me, and make me waſte my ſpirits to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
I wou'd onely take my leave, wiſh you a good Journey, and a 〈◊〉
you when we ſhall ſee you agen; for you will not ſtay long in Heaven I know, there's no Company that you will like Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: None that I like ſo ill as yours Sir—
vexes me ſo, I almoſt faint.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: There are none of your Club Sir, Wits that believe one Stet Divine before all the Twelve Apoſtles Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am quite fainting.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That count his Story true, and all their's a Shamm Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: This Fellow babbles me out of my ſences.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You wou'd babble and ſcribble us out of our Eſtates.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Quite babbl'd me dead, I faint! give me a Cordial! if ever you let him in agen—I'le—Pooh—I can hardly ſpeak—give me that Cordial quickly.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: A Plague on you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! he has ſtartled me with his frightful Curſe! made me ſpill my Cordial, ſlabber my ſelf, and almoſt choak my ſelf; bleſs me! what work's here with this Fellow?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Have I almoſt choak'd thee with a Cordial? then thou art no right Saint, for I have ſeen one of thoſe they call the true Proteſtants, ſwallow another Mans whole eſtate for a Cordial, and never choak himſelf: Choak thee, damn thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Mercy on me! what a curſing and ſwearing the Wretch keeps; to what purpoſe is all this, thou ſilly Fellow? I warrant thou thinkeſt thoſe ſine-Mouth'd Jewels become thee, and art as proud of them as a Cannibal of a Ring in his Noſe: if to be one of the Devils Knights, called an Atheiſt, be a ſine thing, prithee wear a better Badge of thy Order then an Oath or a Curſe, for thoſe are Porterly Badges.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Confound thee, ſink thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Take me away, take me away, I am not able to bear this!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! the diſſemulation of theſe Fellows is pleaſant; but, a Pox on't, we pay too dear for theſe Jeſts, they coſt us confuſion and almoſt ruine: theſe Fellows ſo love diviſion, every one of 'em has two Parties in himſelf.
sp.l: There is in every true Proteſtant Breaſt
A Heraclitus Ridens, his Conteſt,
A Knave in Earneſt, and a Saint in Jeſt.
The Saint looks up to Heaven, the Knave that while
Your Pocket picks, and at the Cheat does ſmile:
Catch him, he, like a Hedge-Hog, ſcrapes your • ury
Ʋnder the Prickles of a ſturdy Jury;
Then, looking out, he does the Hunters brave,
For ſquinting vilely between Saint and Knave:
He looks Ten ways at once, ſo they that watch him,
Cannot tell which he'l take, and never Catch him.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Sir, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is he? that's well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's the new Lord Podeſta's Son,
Mr. Craffy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! my Friend's Son! you muſt let him come in, though he be a very troubleſome Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Oh Friend Florio, are you here?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ay Sir, thanks to my Diſtemper that keeps me priſoner.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Whoo! but are'nt you wi' my Father yonder?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, I profeſs I am here Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: How are you able to be here?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am not able to be any where elſe, I'm ſo ill.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ill? you are dull Man, for if you were not dull, you wou'd go to my Father's Election; if you were giving up the Ghoſt, 'tis better then a thouſand Bear-baitings, ſtay! a Camillo! a Camillo! a Camillo! ſay our party, what do you keep ſuch a bawling for ſuch a Fellow? ſays one of theirs? ſuch a Fellow ſay our Party, and ſet up a laughing and hiſſing, and a hiſſing and a laughing; for all your laughing and hiſſing I'le ſpeak my mind, ſays the Man; will ye ſo? ſays one of our party, and gives him a thump with his Elbow under the ſmall Guts. Now will you ſpeak your mind? ſays our Man; The Man is ſpeechleſs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A good way of ſilencing a Man.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: The beſt we have, ſo upon that ſome of their party began to bear up, but we never gave over till we had quite hiſs'd'em, and hooted'em, and Rogued'em, and Toryed'em out of the Hall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: But who do you think was the Captain of all our Party 〈◊〉 to lead 'em on wherever he ſaw an Enemy? and, I believe, diſcharged Rogue, Rogue, forty times for any Mans once.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Your Chaplain Doctor Sanchy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! he is a zealous Man, where is he? for I want to go to my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Pray? he can't ſpeak he's ſo hoarſe, he's gone to drink a glaſs of Sack to clear his pipes; the truth is, I had as live he ſhou'd pray for me as any body.

sp.speaker: • lo.
sp.p: Why ſo.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Becauſe no Saint in Heaven dare deny him any thing, for if he ſhou'd he'd call him Rogue and Raſcal. Well, but this is not the buſineſs I come to thee about, what doſt think it is?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I cannot gueſs.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Gueſs! no, I'le give thee a thouſand Gueſſes to gueſs it, I will give thee ten thouſand; come, I'le give till this time Twelve-Month, and thou ſhalt think of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Really, I have a little other buſineſs to employ my thoughts about.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Well, I'le put thee out of thy pain, and tell thee the oddeſt thing that ever thou heardeſt in thy life. Thou know'ſt my Father has lately Married the moſt delicate, luſcious—luſcious—luſ—did • ſt ever ſee ſuch a Woman in thy life?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I can't tell, I am paſt thoſe ſtudies now, the young Lady no doubt is handſome enough, but what o'that?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I'm ſtark mad in love with her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In love with your Father's Wife?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, ſo mad for her, that I am quite out o'my Wits; nay, I ha' not only loſt my Wits, but my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The greater loſs of the two.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I can't eat nor drink, I can't ſleep neither; I was once a rare ſleeper, conſta •• ly after Supper my Eyes us'd to call for their Evenings draught and I was no ſooner in bed, but they wou'd tope off fourteen Hours at one go-down Now I tumble and toſs like a Child that has the Worms, Love and Poetry are continually biteing me, I can't pray neither when I fall to my Beads, inſtead of crying Ave Maria, I cry Ave Mother-in-Law, I have given over all ſorts of pleaſures, I read no News, go to no Coffee-houſe, frequent no Club, and take no ſnuff.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why you are come to a ſad paſs.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Introth I am, thou wud'ſt ſay ſo if thou knew'ſt all, and I come to thee, to beg of thee, as ever thou woud'ſt ſave the life of an Honeſt young Fellow of thy own party, and a true Whig as I hope to be ſav'd, to lend me a little of thy aſſiſtance, for thou art a rare Fellow at Wenching, know'ſt all the tricks of Women, and ha'ſt great power over my Mother.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And ſo I muſt procure her for you Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, prithee do now, prithee dear Rogue do now; Brother Whig, Brother Whig, prithee dear Brother Whig do now.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Brother Whig! thou horrid Wretch, Brother to the Devil, art thou in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Why thou horrid Fool, Brother to a Cha • gling, doſt think I come to hear my ſelf prate?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then wou'dſt thou Cuckold thy Father, thou Monſter?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Wou'd I not if I cou'd, thou Monſter? wou'd any thing refuſe to lye with ſuch a ſweet Creature but a Monſter?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Wou'd any thing but the horrid'ſt Villain upon Earth, endeavor to diſhonour his Fathers Bed?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Wou'd any thing but the horrid'ſt Aſs upon Earth, ſay a luſty young Fellow ſhall not honour his Fathers Bed more then an old fumbler that diſgraces it!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then 'tis a thing of reputation with thee to commit Inceſt?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Inceſt? prithee don't trouble me with hard names, I don't think it is any more Inceſt to lye with the ſame woman my Father does, then to drink in the ſame Glaſs, or ſit in the ſame Pue at Church.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is there no difference between your Fathers Wife and his Pue?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: He makes none, for they onely both lay him to ſleep. I would make a difference, I confeſs, in the ſweet uſe, not that I think his Wife more ſacred then his Pue, for the locking of a Man to a Woman in Marriage, or in a Pue in a Church, are onely a couple of Church-tricks to get Money, one for the Prieſt, and tother for the Sexton; that's all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You are a fine Fellow.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I would I were ſo fine a Fellow as to pleaſe my Mother-in-Law, and I wou'd not change to be thee, if thou wert at thy beſt; And I do all I can to be a fine Fellow, it coſts me the Lord knows what in one Beauty-Water or another to mend my Face, and a Pox on't, I'm never the handſomer; prithee ha'ſt e're a Looking-glaſs to ſee how I look?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why, if thou look'ſt never ſo well, doſt thou think thou could'ſt charm thy Mother into an Inceſtuous Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p:
What a robuſt word is there? look thee I underſtand Trap,
and ſo does ſhe, I kiſt her behind 'tother day, that is, I came behind and kiſt her, pretending I took her for the Waiting-Woman, and ſhe let me, pretending ſhe took me for my Father; a rank Sham o'both ſides, we had both a mind to kiſs, and there's an end; And I ſwear ſhe let me rumple thoſe ſweet Lips of hers as patiently as a Mercer will let a good Cuſtomer do his Silks in hopes to put'em off.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ha! I'm glad you tell me this Sir, ſince ſhe is ſo weak a piece, I'le fortifie her.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: With Godly Counſels! putting forces into her Head will never fortifie her Tayl, what ſignifies fortifying the Capital City, when the remote Provinces rebell?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I ſhall bring down the Prince of the Country, your Father Sir, upon you, who if he cannot quell the rebellion, ſhall deal with you.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p:
Why thou wu't not betray me, wu't thou? I never knew a religious Fool that was not a Rogue in my life; I tell thee what, if thou doſt tell my Father I would lye with his Wife, Egad I'le ſwear to him thou doſt lye with her, and I'le bring a hundred Witneſſes to 〈◊〉
it, beſides Corroboraters.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Yes that I will, I'le teach you to play the Knave, you ſtinking damn'd Fellow you, I'm going now by my Fathers order to ſearch the Cathedral for Arms to affront the Clergy, and make 'em ſuſpected for Plotters; now, inſtead of Arms, I'le ſearch for Swearers, and if they catch you by the back, they'I ſhake you worſe then an Ague, and be harder to cure then the Pox Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: There is a way to be cur'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, Twelve Proteſtant Conſciences cleanly pickt, not one or 'tother ſide amongſt 'em, are as certain a Cure of an Evidence, as Jeſuites Powder of an Ague, Probatum eſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Come back, thou art ſuch a Villain, I know
not what to do with thee.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: And thou art ſuch a Knave, I know not what to do with thee, Pox on me for truſting thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If I ſhould conceal thy wickedneſs, thou wouldſt proceed in it.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I will proceed, whether thou concealeſt it or no.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And ruine thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I don't know whether I have a Soul or no.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If I tell thy Father—

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Then I'le forſwear it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And hide your Roguery with perjury?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, and be a true Proteſtant for all that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And break your Fathers Heart?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I'll come the ſooner to his Eſtate, and the eaſier to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh fine Fellow! Well Sir, out of love to your good Father, whoſe Heart this news wou'd break; and out of love to the City, whoſe ſafety depends much upon your wiſe Fathers Conduct, I will conce • l this; but I'le watch you.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Watch and be Hang'd—I wou'd watch thee for my Mother, but that ſhe knows thou art ſuch a foul ruſ • y Gun, if ſhe ſhou'd diſcharge thee, thou woud'ſt flye in pieces, and hazard her life too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Away you Monſter.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Away you Godly fa • ſe Puppy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I am glad the Fool gave me this notice. I do not know
But my ſair • ove, like an o're-ſertile Field,
May breed rank Weeds, if ſhe be idly Til • 'd;
Leaſt Love for Fools ſhou'd in her Boſome live,
She ſhall have all the Tillage I can give.

div.head: Scene the Street.
div.stage: Enter the Governour of the City, Artall, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: This fooliſh head-ſtrong City will chuſe that factious troubleſome Coxcomb Paulo Camillo for their Podeſta.

div.stage: A Shout, A Paulo, a Paulo.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: A brave Paulo, we ha' carryed thee Boy!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Is this Gentleman Elected?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Yes that he is, for all the tricks that were us'd to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I thought his Excellency the Vice-Roy had given you intimation another perſon wou'd be more pleaſing to him, and in this juncture more ſitting for the Office.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Another Man more fit to be Podeſta then me? then I ſhall think another Man more fit to be Vice-Roy then he, and ſo I'le make bold humbly to acquaint His Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Are we to follow the Vice-Roys pleaſure, or our own conſciences?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here's ſawcy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What are you Sir, that undertake thus impudently for all the reſt?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: 'Tis well known what I am, I am a Freeman of Naples, a Bricklayer by Trade.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Oh I have heard of a buſie pragmatical Fellow that calls himſelf the Catholick Brick-layer, are you he Sir?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I am not bound by Law to give an account what I am; if any one has any thing to ſay to me, let him deal with me according to Law.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: But Sir, you might be ſo civil as to make me an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I'le do nothing for no Man, but according to Law.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My Lord, the Man as to his occupation is but a mean Man, but as to his abilities, he makes a very conſiderable Figure.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: He is a pretty Figure indeed.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: We have a Charter for the free Election of our Magiſtrate, and what we have done, our Charter will juſtifie.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Have you a Charter to be ſawey Sir?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What I ſpeak is according to Law, and I may ſpeak Law in defence of our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Come, pray be ſilent, 'tis according to Law alſo for me to ſpeak, His Excellence the Vice-Roy has been pleaſed to oppoſe my Election, ſtimulated thereunto by evil Men, Enemies to the City and Nation, they wou'd betray and ſell us to the French, and they'r angry ſo active a Man as I am put over the City to prevent their wicked Machinations; for that reaſon I will be ten times more active.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: A Pox of an active Rogue.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Who are theſe evil Men you ſpeak of, Indict 'em and prove 'em Guilty, and I'le engage the Vice-Roy will ſeverely puniſh 'em.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I don't know who they are, all's one for that, I'm ſure there are ſuch Traytors, though I don't know who they are, and French-Men, though I don't know where they are, and Plots, though I don't know what they are, and I'le make work.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: May not you be deceived?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
No, I'm never deceived; for the preſervation therefore of the Town, I wi • l have four Regiments of the Train bands be upon the
〈◊〉 , during my whole Year; and I, or my Officers, will every four and twenty Hours ſearch every Houſe in the City.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: At this rate you will not let people be quiet in their Houſes.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
No▪ nor out of their Houſes neither, I will have no Ranting, Rev • l •• ng, Gameing, Drinking, no nor Eating immoderat • ly; I will have
〈…〉 eat and drink according to Law, and I will have all Mens Tables examined to ſee if there be no Letters cou • ey'd into their Diſhes from the French, and if I find but the leaſt cauſe of ſuſpition, I'le take their dinners into cuſtody; I will have all perſons be in bed at the ringing of the Nine-a-Clock Bell; and I, or my Officers, will ſee 'em i'bed, and ſee who they have a bed with 'em too.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here's a fine buſineſs, pox o'thee and thy Officers, ſhall we neither eat, drink, nor lye a bed in quiet, for thee and thy Officers?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Poxo' me and my Officers? Pox o' your Wenches Sir, I'll make you know I am a Magiſtrate; Seize him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: And have I no Authority, that you offer to Seize him in my preſence?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Yes, we know your Authority, know you are Military Governour of the City, Captain of the Vice Roys Guards, a Lord, nay more then all this, a Juſtice of Peace, and twenty things more; what do we care for all that, we are in the City Liberties, and what we do is according to Law.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hold your prateing Si • rah.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He ſays truth.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: It may be according to Law, but 'tis unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: All's one, 'tis according to Law.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: But Sir, this Gentleman is an Officer under me, and you have not power over him, therefore I adviſe you not to meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Have a care what you do, do nothing but according to Law.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Have you a care of adviſing me, I know what I do, I'll do nothing but according to Law.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Nor I neither, for I have Authority by Law to Protect my Officer by force, if you uſe force; but becauſe I'll make no diſturbance, let him alone, and I'll paſs my word for him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: If the Law will let him alone, do, otherwiſe not.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Will you not take my Word?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Adviſe with Counſel.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Adviſe me agen! I know what I do, I will adviſe with Counſel!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Adviſe with Counſel whether my Word's to be taken, or no; Guards, force Artall out of their Hands, and take that Raſcally Brick-layer into Cuſtody, [Brick layer is ſeiz'd. and let me ſee who dares reſiſt. Now Sirrah, though I cou'd puniſh you by Law for your inſolence, ſince you are a Freeman, I will not diſturb the City-Feſtival with the puniſhment o'the leaſt o'their Members, though they deſerve it not; therefore Sirrah, if any of your great Friends here will be bound for your good behaviour, I'll releaſe you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: 'Tis beneath my Dignity, though I reſpect the Man.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Who elſe will be bound for him? No-body? You ſee, Sirrah, for what ſpecial Friends you leave you Trade and venture your Neck.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Hang 'em, I knew the Rogues were of untemper'd Mortar: A word with you Sir in private—Procure me a Pention, I'll come over to your Party.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: A Pention! a Whip you Raſcal; go Sirrah, I give you liberty, follow your Trade, and mind all of you your own matters, leave State affairs to your Governours, we have more to loſe than any of you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I don't know that I have a hundred thouſand pound to loſe, and that's enough for one Man; but however my Lord, if you pleaſe to introduce me to His Excellence the Vice-Roy—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What to be—? I underſtand you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How the Devil came he to underſtand my mind ſo well?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I muſt tell you plainly, I don't care to do ſo ungrateful an Office to His Excellency, for I know his mind very well, I know, till you have a better introducer then my ſelf, I mean your good management of affairs, you will not be very welcome to him, nor receive any honour from him. And ſo Farwel my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Say ye ſo, ſhall I not be welcome to him? then he ſhan'not be Welcome to me; And ſince he'l do me no Honour, I'll do his Government not Honour. My Wife, for want of this Knighthood, will lead me an ill life; and I for want of it will lead him an ill life, ſince he is ſo huffy and ſtormy, I'll be a Storm.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
A Whirlwind, that ſhall rumble and roar over his head, tear open Doors by day and by night, toſs his Friends out of their Coaches and Beds into Goals; nor ſhall all the Preachings, and Pulpit-Charms
〈◊〉 their Prieſts
Diſpoſſeſs me, or fright me in the leaſt,
A Whig's a Devil that can caſt out a Prieſt.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT, the Second.
div.stage: Enter Podeſta, Citizens; Scene the Podeſta's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: NOt Knight me? when he knew I was a proud Man, very proud Man, oppos'd him out o'pride, and a Knighthood might ha' bought me. He ſhall repent it.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Welcome home my Lord, I wiſh you joy of your new Honour.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Thank you Sweet-heart, I am glad I'm in a capacity to do my Country ſervice, but I'm ſorry I can't do you the ſervice you affect.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What's that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Give you laſting Honour, The Title I ſhall beſtow on you will live no longer then a Graſhopper or a Silk-Worm, 'twill dye at the end of the Year, your preſent Title of Ladyſhip will then dye into an Aldermans Wife, for I am not Knighted.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Not Knighted?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Not Knighted.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: How dare they uſe you thus?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: They are deſperate.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I'm troubled.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I was born well, and I affect Honour.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I know it, I know your ſpirit better then you do your ſelf, and am pleas'd with your affection to Honour, for Honour is an excellent guard to Vertue, I know you are punctually juſt to me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Am I? I think I am.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Out of a point of Honour I know it, ſcorning to appear what you are not; not out of dulneſs and want of gayety you affect pleaſures and follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Out of a point of Honour, to appear what you are, I know you, know your temper perfectly.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So perfectly you amaze me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh! I have a penitrating judgment, know your paſſion for Honour, highly commend it, and would gratifie it if I could, but ſince I cannot, I will give you a kind of Honour, Revenge. The methods you muſt leave to me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Give me Greatneſs, and do you keep Policy.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well carv'd.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So, I have nurs'd the Wenn of his Vanity, till it has blinded his Eyes, and made him miſtake his affection for mine; what I really affect, he is never like to ſee, and that's only my dear Florio.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p:
Your Servant Sir, I am much beholding to you, and the reſt of
my Breth • ren of the City for the kindneſs you ſhew'd me to day in refuſing to be bound for me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'll anſwer you Sir, we reſolv'd to go prudently to work, we did not know but they might have laid Treaſon to your charge, ſo we reſolv'd to ſee whether they durſt have Try'd you, and if they had Try'd you, whether they durſt have brought you in Guilty, and if they had brought you in Guilty, whether they durſt have Hang'd you, and if they had Hang'd you—then let 'em look to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And who ſhou'd ha' lookt to me then? a very fine buſineſ • , come, come, this was ſcurvy, but I'll ſtick to the cauſe whilſt I have drop of blood.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p:
Ha • there's my delicate Mother-in Law, that ever ſuch a curious Appendix ſhould be bound up with ſuch a Volum •
〈…〉
cover'd with Calves Leather, as that old Fellow is, I will t • a • her 〈◊〉
him, I'll be hang'd if ſhe loves him; and as for Marriage-promiſes, they are but Church-Mouth-Glue, they won't hold a couple together Three Days.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh are you come Sir? well, what ha' you done Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: A delicate Woman!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir? are you aſleep Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: No, nor a • ed Sir, wou'd I were wi' your Wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What are you •• areing on Sir? why don't you give me an Account of what I ſent you about? did not I ſend you to ſearch the Cathedral for Arms Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod
sp.p: And what ha' you done Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Sir, I have been ſearching—ſearching—ſearching— Sir—that Mother-in-Law—

sp.speaker: Pod
sp.p: Searching your Mother-in-Law Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: The Cathedral, the Cathedral I mean Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: S • rrah, you ſaid Mother-in Law.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Why is not a Cathedral a Mother-Church Sir?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: S • rrah, you ſaid Mother in-Law.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Why is not a Cathedral according to Law Sir? I ſpoke jeeringly, and you k • ow we uſe to jeer the Church Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: That's true.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Lord Sir, muſt I teach you the language of your own Family?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, did the Prieſts let you come in patiently?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—fiddle—faddle—a delicate Woman!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: That's very ſtrange, then they are not afraid o' me?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I hope ſhortly to leave never a Prieſt in Chriſtendome, they call themſelves the Pillars o' truth, they are rather the Whipping-Poſts o' truth, and Sign-poſts of Faction.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'll handle greater people then they.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I muſt have this Woman, if Courtſhip won • t do, Love-powder ſhall.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Come Sir, I'll try your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd upon Love-powder.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I can put the City in Arms, upon pretence of a French Invaſion, but when they ſee no invaſion, and the fright is over, how ſhall I keep up that Army?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: The beſt way will be by Love-powder.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How! keep up an Army by Love-powder? you impudent, illmanner'd unnatural Raſcal you, do you jeer your Father?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Sir, I don't jeer you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sirrah, you either jeer me, or which is almoſt as ſawcy, did not attend to what I ſaid.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Well, I confeſs my Wits were a Wool-gathering, and I beg your pardon Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: A Wool-gathering? a Whore-gathering by your ſtory of Love-powder, you ſawcy debauched Fop you, when your Father condeſcends to talk wiſely to you of State-affairs, muſt your brains be rambling after Wenches?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Wenches are • itter for me then State-affairs Sir; what a Duce ſhou'd ſuch a young Fellow as I trouble himſelf with State-affairs for?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Who us'd to trouble themſelves and others too about State-affairs more then you Sir? were you not ſuch a tempeſtuous diſputer in Coffee-houſes, that as ſoon as ever you appear'd in one, both ſides wou'd run away, our Friends out of envy, and our Enemies out of fear.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: 'Tis my caſe, no Man will ſit by me in a Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Were not your Writings like ſo many Fire-drakes? no Printer wou'd meddle with 'em, no perſon come near 'em.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: His things are very near my Stile, and I am forc'd to Print all my things at my own charge.

sp.speaker: Pod.
Craf.
sp.p: A Tory? that's a good one, when I'm now Writing an Anſwer to Abſolom and Achitophel.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Tis true indeed, he read part of it to my Maid laſt night.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: He did indeed Madam, and 'tis very fine.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: May be that puzzles his Head then.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nay, if it be ſo, I ſhall not be angry with him, for o' my Word▪ a good Anſwer to that wou'd do us ſervice.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And 'twill require pains.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: It will do ſo, if he employs his time and thoughts ſo well as that▪ I ſhall be very well ſatisfied; what do you call this Poem?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: A •• riah and Huſhai.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: A very good ſubject.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Well choſen.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Is not this a ſtrange thing now, that you who are no Poet, not underſtand Poetry no more then a Cat, ſhould lye inſulting o're a Man o' ſence, when he is breaking his brains for the ſervice and honour of you and your party?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, well Craffy, I did not know it, I did not know it.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Not know it? then you ſhou'd not meddle with that you do not underſtand, I muſt break my ſleep, and ſpoil my ſtomach in ſtudying to do you ſervice, and be call'd a Villain and a Tory?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, well Child, I am ſorry, I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Sorry? what does your ſorryneſs ſignifie? ſuppoſe your vexing me ſhou'd make me Write but a ſorry Poem, as twenty to one but it will, and ſo I'll go burn what I ha' done, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nay prithee Child.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Prithee dear Child.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Hay I will.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: No, prithee Child, let me ſee what thou haſt done, and finiſh the remainder.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Prithee do now, 'twill joy my heart.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I ſay I won't.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This it is to breed our Sons Wiſer then our ſelves, we are deſpiſed for our pains.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Look, if he has not made his good Father weep; are not you a croſs-grain'd ill-natur'd Fellow to make your old Father weep? what if he be not ſo good a Poet and Schollar as you, he has as good natural parts, and better.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He is ungrateful to me, for what learning he has, my purſe paid for; but I alwaies find over-much wit and learning make people inſolent, and when alls done, a Fool's a better comfort to his Parents, then one of theſe great Wits.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Go fetch the Poem, and be Whipt to you.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Do Mr. Craffy, 'twill obliege your Father and me both.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Will it obliege your Lor'ſhip Madam? to do that I'll run a Thouſand Miles upon my bea • Head, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'm glad he pays ſo much reſpect to you, Sweetheart, though he will pay none to me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he will, but great Wits are humour ſome.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nay, the Boy has excellent parts, that's certain, but when all done, tis but a folly to breed Boys up to this heighth, for it does but ſpoil them, and all buſineſs, for they will be a top o' bus'neſs, riding upon old Mens backs, and ſo the old Men go lamely, and the Boys ride madly, and the bus'neſs goes awkardly.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
Wom.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Did not you ſay Craffy fell aſleep laſt night in reading his own Verſes, and when he wak'd, forgat 'em in your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Run quickly and bring 'em to me.

div.stage: Enter Florio wrapt in his Cloak.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh! how do you good Mr. Florio?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Thank you good my Lord, the better to ſee things go ſo well, that you are choſen.

sp.speaker: Pod
sp.p: Oh! we carried clearly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ay, ſo my Chaplain Dr. Sanchy ſaid, who I think labour'd for my Lord.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Ay indeed, he took great pains, there was ſcarce a Man appear'd 'gainſt my Lord, that he did not call Rogue and Raſcal a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
He is a zealous Man, and ſo ſeldome calls any Man by his Chriſten name, that he is ſuſpected to be an Anabaptiſt, and againſt Chriſtening— Oh! dear Madam, is your Ladyſhip here? when I came into the Room, I ſaw a Lady, and turn'd my head aſide, as my uſual manners
is when I ſee Women, for they ha' been no good Friends o' mine, and ſo I did not mind your Ladyſhip, I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Oh! it needs not Sir, I am very glad to ſee you look ſo well.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay truly, Mr. Florio looks very fine and freſh ruddy and plump, methinks I have hopes of him; what ſays your Doctors Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Alas! my Lord, they have given me over long ſince, all my truſt is in an incomparable Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Pray who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: As you came along my Lord, you might ha' ſeen her ty'd by a Rope to my door.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ty'd with a Rope? what is ſhe a mad Woman?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord, a Cow, my Lord, a Cow.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: A Cow?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ay my Lord, ha' not I mannag'd my ſelf well, to bring my ſelf from one of thoſe they call one of the Wits of the Kingdom, to be one of the Calves, and live upon the breaſts of a poor Beaſt, for thence I have all my ſubſiſtence.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Alack! yet your Face ſays you are as well as ever you were in your life, I proteſt it does.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Face is as falſe as ever my heart was, it might have more innocence, for it is ſcarce two Months old, I mean the Fleſh of it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, I warrant if you were to begin the World agen, you would have none of the mad frolicks you had?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I think I ſhould not, I laught once at mad Fellows that in drunken frolicks eat • ire, but was not I more mad to belch Fire at Heaven it ſelf, as I have often done in my abominable talk? but what did I get by it? he threw it all back agen in my Face, and almoſt conſum'd me. Man is a ſhallow Animal, can bear no exceſs, too much Wit makes him as mad as too much Wine, and a little over ſets him; yet he thinks his ſilly Scull contains all things, rules all things, and Omnipotence it ſelf is afraid of that pittiful Engine.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: When all that the moſt hot-brain'd Fellow in the world can do, is to make a ſmoak to darken things, he can't ſtrike Fire enough out of himſelf to light him into the nature of a Fly. But 'tis time we went to Prayers. Doctor Sanchy.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'm a comming.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Good Doctor give us a few Prayers.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Ay if you will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord being a Magiſtrate, I think Doctor you muſt read the Prayers of the Church.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'll ſee 'em burnt firſt, and all Prieſts hang'd, before I read any of their Prayers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The Law commands i • .

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Therefore I won't do it, I'll be commanded by nothing, and do nothing I'm commanded.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: For matter o' Law, we can eaſily come off, no body dare indict us.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But for matter o' Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Hang Conſcience, I do it out o' matter of Honour, and matter of Revenge, the Prieſts are Raſcals and ſlight me, and I'll ſlight their Prayers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We ſhoul'd not be humourſome in our Prayers Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'll do what I pleaſe, or I'll do nothing.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Pray let him, for we are all oblieg'd to the Doctor for the aſſiſtance he gave my Election.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He had need of it, there was a damn'd Company o' Rogues appeared againſt you, I hope to ſee 'em all hang'd.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: There was one great Man.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: A great Rogue, he deſerves to be burnt.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: There was a great lady very buſie.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: A great Whore, ſhe deſerves to be whipt, I hope to ſee all ſuch Rogues and Whores whipt out of the Kingdom; but come let us go to Prayers.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: O the Devil, the Devil!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: I ha' loſt my Huſhai, I can't find it high nor low. Who ſaw my Huſhai?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What the Poem that you read to me, that was an anſwer to Abſalom?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I had rather ha' loſt ten pounds out o' my own Pocket.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Then do you like it Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: 'Twas an admirable thing! 'twould ha' made the Rogue that writ Abſalom hang himſelf; look about for this Huſhai.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Won't you go to Prayers firſt Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Hang Prayers! this is a thing of forty times the conſequence we may pray at any time, or if we never pray at all, 'tis no great matter, it is but a thing of form to pleaſe the people; look for this Huſhai. I'll look for't my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Who the Devil has got my Huſhai?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Is Mr. Craffy here?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Well Sir, what wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I come from the Club, they ſtay for you Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: The Club be damn'd, I can't come, I ha' loſt my Huſhai.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What Club is it?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: The Club o' young pollitick Whigs, you know 'em.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh Craffy, you muſt go to 'em, they are all perſons of Quality.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: What care I for their quality, they are but a company o' young Coxcombs, I won't looſe my Huſhai for 'em.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are a ſawcy fellow to call young Men o' their parts and quality, Coxcombs, they are admitted into better Company then yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, to help to pay reckonings, flatter an old Knaves vanity, and give a Guinny to the burning of a Pope.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, ſome of 'em have had the honour to ſit in great Caballs.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I wonder they cou'd.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Why ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Becauſe ſome of 'em were ſo lately whipt at School for Blockheads. I wonder they could ſit any where, they have the marks of Fools both before and behind, and if ever they ſpeak, the mark's in their Mouths.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I don't like this Fellow.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sirrah, I now begin to ſuſpect you agen for a Tory, and get you to 'em, or I'll not onely Cudgel you, but diſinherit you.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Take notice if I go to 'em, I ſhall be very drunk.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I care not if you be in ſuch company as they are.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Your Wiſe's Honeſty may pay for't, for I ſhall be very impudent when I am drunk;
look all for my Huſhai.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What elſe!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So, we are rid of one Fool, cou'd we have as good luck with the reſt!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What is become of this Huſhai, ſome conceal'd Rogue has burnt it out of Envy.

sp.speaker: Coffee-Boy.
sp.p: Doctor you muſt come to the Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Muſt come?

sp.speaker: Coffee-boy.
sp.p: Ay, to a perſon of quality.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: That perſon of quality is a Coxcomb, and you are a ſawcy Raſcal; muſt come?

sp.speaker: Coffee-boy.
sp.p: 'Tis the lame Lord.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He is a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Coffee-boy.
sp.p: Your Friend.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Oh! then I'll come, but look all about for this Huſhai.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Do ſo, and let me have an account of it when I come home.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Are you a going abroad my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes Sweetheart, and ſhall not come home theſe three hour,
Mr. Florio, you'l excuſe me, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! good my Lord!
Ha! rid of all my diſeaſes at once!
I mean my Fools, and left alone with my health! my Roſaura!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: My life! my Florio!

div.stage: They embrace, and Enter Podeſta and Bricklayer.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Roſaura!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: My Husband! faint, • aint in my arms, help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Mr. Florio is fal'n into an Appopleptick Fit, and dyes in my arms.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Alas poor Gentleman! who there? [Enter Pietro. help in with your Maſter, and call a Doctor, I'm cruelly afraid he'l go away in one of theſe Fits.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, here's an old Counſellour, Bartoline, lighted at your door, and is coming up to ſpeak with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This old Lawyer is a ſtrange Fellow, he is very old, and very rich, and yet follows the Term, as if he were to begin the World.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: He has loſt all his Teeth that he can hardly ſpeak, and he will be pleading for his • ee; but he's of our ſide, and ſo we muſt not ſpeak againſt him.

div.stage: Lawyer. [Enter Bartoline, Lucinda, and (at a diſtance) Artall.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What pretty Country Creature's this! I cannot but venture inafter her; the Podeſta's Houſe is publique, and ſo I ſhall not be taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Where's my Lord Poſhta? hah! where iſh he?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Here, here, old Friend, do not you ſee me?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No, ſaid my eyſh are none of the beſht.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You follow the Term ſtill?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, and will aſh long aſh I live, yer'ſh no cauſh wi'out me.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: How can you follow all Cauſes?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ye'y follow me, ye'y will ha'me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What young Gentlewoman ha' you brought with you here 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: One I may be aſham'd on—ſheſh my folly, yat iſh cho ſhay my Wife—I ha' playd ye fool, and Married a young Garle.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Thy Wife? if thou beeſt her Husband, thou ſhalt be my Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Welcome to Town Madam.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Welcome Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Iſh ſhe not pritchy? you ſhee I have a ſhweet chooth in my head ſhtill.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sweet Tooth? you ha' never a Tooth in your head.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yatſh chrue, but I'll bite for all yet wr' my Wit.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Why would you Marry ſuch a young thing as this?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: A Man of fourſcore be ſo fond? he, 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
A Man of foaſhco—yerſh no ſhuch thing, ye are Boyſh or foaſhſco—if you will, after 'hreeſhco we ought cho go in long coa • h, for breecheſh are impoſh chureſh and preechen • cho that 〈…〉
I believe my Lord Poſhta you are behind-hand wi' your 〈…〉
aſh I, I believe ſho—hah!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Though I be, I ſhall ſuffer no diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: How do you know yat?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Becauſe I married a vertuous Woman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A vartuouſh Woman? why ſho did I for ought I kno may be bo'h mi • hchaken.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: No, I am never miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh you'r a happy Man, I ha'no ſhuch confidentſh in a Woman I declare it before my Girleſh faiſh, I'll waſh her wacherſh.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Do if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And for yat reaſhon I have brought her hither, deſhire you tho' let her be in your houſh; yourſh is a ſhivil Family, and here ſhe'l have a great yeale of good company, yat will chake off her fanſhy from going abro • d and playing ye foole.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: So, • ow I ſhall know where to find her.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What wou'd you h • ' me keep a Boarding-houſe?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What do you ſhtand upon ſheremonyeſh with an old Friend fo •• you and I have known one anoyer fortchy years, and when y'are in bed with your Wife, yerſh ſhome'hing about you doſh confeſh you cho be old. Come, if you'l let me be here, I'll give your Wife a Jewel, and you a peiſh o' Plate, and I'll pay a good rate beſhideſh; what chay you cho y'iſh now, Huh?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Will my Lady conſhent? for I believe de Mareſh de letcher hoiſh.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My Will is hers.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I wou'd know 'yat of her.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: She is buſied now in a work of Charity, about a poor Gentleman, that's faln in an Appoplectick Fit, I don't know whether he • l recover it, if he does, he can't live long, he's in a deep Conſumption, I ſhou'd be ſorry to looſe him, though in point o' Money, I ſhould be a gainer by his death, for he will leave us a very good Legacy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A Legaſhy? huh!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, for he's a rich Batchelor.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What a Kinſhman?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: No kin at all, but he has a great Friendſhip for us becauſe we are a ſtrict ſober Family, and he is a mighty Religious Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh! I know this Religious Rogue, 'tis Florio.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Will he leave you money, becauſh you are ſhober? huh!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You muſt know he was a great follower of naughty Women, and now he feels the ſad conſequence, and has a great value for Vertue, and I believe will leave my Wife a great part of his eſtate, becauſe ſhe is a vertuous Woman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Do you hear Girl? you are fal'n incho a brave houſh, where you may get money by Vartſhow and Shobrietchy; Come, my Lord, what will you have, I'll pay you any rate, Come.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You and I will not fall out.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ha! is he a providing a Florio for his Wife? I'll provide him a Florio. By good luck I have an Indian-Gown and Cap at the door, juſt new out of the Shop.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What iſh yiſh Gentlemanſh name?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Florio.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh! y're ish shuch a Man; I never shaw him, but I have heard of him, a great debosh, wash he not? and a good witshy Fellow.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh! a very witty man, and a wicked man too once, but now the moſt penitent creature in the world, and he had need be ſo, he is going out of it, he cannot live many Months.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Alash poor man, and when he dyesh he'l leave all hish money to Vartuoush people will he? huh.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays 'tis ſowing Seed in good ground; well • ha • ſome occaſions call me away, you may be here if you will, old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Ay, let him, let him, and come away about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hark you, hark you! Sho, yish wash very lucky, Girl you mush make it your buyshnesh cho get iucho yish Genklemansh favour by your Shobriechy, and you may mump my Lady Poſhta of hish Eschate for oughteh I know.

div.stage: Enter Artall in a Night-Gown and Cap, a Patch on his Noſe, led by Two Servants.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I grow weaker and weaker every day, my time draws on, Heaven prepare me for my Change, yet I'll uſe the means to live. Give me my Milk.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I my Conſciensh, yish ish de Genkleman!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Give me my Milk I ſay you Raſcals: what have I ſaid? indeed I shou'd not call any thing out of it's name, I ask your pardon for it.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Ah Sir! ask your poor Servants pardon?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ay and thank you too, if you will give it me. I was ſo accuſtom'd in the days of my wickedneſs to Libell every thing, I cannot leave the ill habit ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, yish ish he, yish ish he sharchainly.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Truth is, Atheiſm is nothing elſe but a Libell on the whole Creation, calling it the Off-ſpring of paltry Chance, when 'tis the Child of Heaven, that I ought to ask pardon of every Dog for detracting from his diſcent; But give me my Milk, and ſet me a Chair to repoſe my ſel • , for I am very weak.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Alack! alack! yish ish de poor Gentleman; But what a 'hing it ish y'at yish young Fellow shou'd bring himshelush inchoshuch a shad condition: let me she how he looksh!

div.stage: Puts on his Spectacles, and looks on Artall, whilſt Artall holds the Pot to his Noſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Certainly this handſome ſick Gentleman is the • ine unhappy Mr. Florio, I have heard ſo much talk of, a thouſand pitties ſuch a delicate Gentleman ſhou'd bring himſelf to this!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He lookſh very white—odſha' me—'twaſh the white potch—ay 'twaſh the potch, and he looks very rudgy, but men in yat g •• t will do ſho, ay yey will do ſho.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh! Florio, Florio!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh! now I am ſhachiſhfyed, 'tish he.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
How haſt thou brought on this Youth all the Infirmities of Age? my eyes are dim, my breath is short, my Limbs are weak, Limbs did I ſay? I have none, at leaſt of Heaven's making: I have Imbezell'd all
the Furniture of my Soul and body in vice, though Heaven gave me an excellent Houſe-keeper to look to it all, a careful wakeful Creature, call'd a Conſcience, which never ſlept, never let me ſleep in ill, but I abus'd her, ſought to turn her out of doors, nay, Murder her, but cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I procheſht yiſh iſh very ſhad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Exceeding pittiful.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Aſham'd of her I was, and to all my Atheiſtical Companions deny'd her, at the ſame time ſhe ſtar'd me in the face; 'Tis the Athieſts trick to hide his Conſcience as the Tradeſman does his Wench, for fear of ſpoyling his Credit, and looſing his Traffique with thoſe ill people, who will not come near him if he owns ſo ſcandalous a thing as a Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſwear he almoſt makes me weep.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly I am chroubled, and I don't uſhe cho be ſho.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But ala! let him hide her for a time, when diſeaſes and death come and ſhake the building in pieces, as now they do mine, the poor foul Conſcience will appear through all the Rubbiſh, and call out mercy, mercy, when it may be 'tis too late; thank Heaven for the fair warning I have had; Is my Coffin ready?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Dear Sir, why does your Honour think of a Coffin? 'tis time enough to talk of that forty years hence.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh! prithee don't flatter my craz'd body, I cannot live, I hang on the Eves of life, like a trembling drop, ready every minute to fall and be ſeen no more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Alaſh, alaſh.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Oh! dear, and pleaſe your Honour, here is company, I doubt your Honour intrenches on a Gentleman's Chamber?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Heaven forbid! where is the Gentleman? I beg your pardon Sir a thouſand times; my good friend the new Lord Podeſta, you know Sir, is a ſober, diſcreet, frugal perſon, hates the vanity and prodigality of ſplendid Houſe-keeping, and ſo I ſuppo • e, may content himſel •
with a part of this Houſe, and oblige a friend with the remainder; if you be the friend, I beg your pardon Sir, I wou'd ha' gone up higher, but truly I wanted breath.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly, you ſhay chrue Shir, my Lord yo'ſh oblige me with part of hiſh houſh, which part, or the whole houſh, if it were mine, ſhou'd be at your ſherviſh, good Mr. Florio.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do you know me Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
No Shir, but I have heard muſh of your great partſh, and my
Lord Poſhto chellſh me what a good man you are, and I have heard it choo wi' my own earſh.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: May I crave your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I am call'd Barcholine Shir, I am a Fellow pritchy well known among Lawyerſh..

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The famous Counſellor Bartoline?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have ſome Repuchation in y'at way Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I am glad to know your Sir, I think I ſee a young Woman there, very young—is ſhe your Grand-Child Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly Shir, I am almoſht aſham'd cho chell you ſhe is my Wife.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh dear! wou'd you Marry one ſo young Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I wanched a comfort for my Age Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And ſhe wants a comfort for her Youth, Heaven that made both Sexes, wou'd have both provided for, can pou provide for hers?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Whatch I want in Proviſionſh I make up in a heartchy Welcome—hah!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But will that ſuffice her?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It may in chime, cuſhtome iſh a great matcher, I have obſherved luſhty Sou'dies by cuſtome got cho dine and ſhup very comforchably on a pipe o' Chobacco.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But they ſteal many a good bit that no body knows of.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly ſhe may Shir, but not if ſhe be honeſht.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Many an honeſt Pariſhoner follows private Meetings, becauſe he finds no comfort from the Parſon of the Pariſh, but ſhe ſeems a vertuous, modeſt, young Lady, and I wou'd pay my reſpects to her in a ſalute, but I fear my breath may offend her, pray excuſe me to her Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh! good Shir, well ſhir, ſhe and I are cho chaken with the diſcourſheſh we have heard fall from you, y'at we are exſhtreamly deſhirouſh to be frequently wi' you Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Alas Sir! I am unfit for company, my good Lady Podeſta indeed will fit by me half a day here, as by a murmuring Brook that ſlides faſt away, and ſoon will be dryed up for ever, and ſhe is content to hear my little purlings.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Ay yey are very well ingeed Shir, very well, and you wou'd much obliegſh uſh, my Wife wantſh ſhuch good company, ſheſh a
• oung creature, yat never in Chown before, and yos'h not know the World Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Is it poſſible! ſweet Madam, you are fail'd into a dangerous Gulph which few young Ladies paſs without caſting away their Reputations,
or Honeſtys, or both; I have been an Admiral here, and you ſee to what I am brought!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well Shir, affairſh call me away, I'll make bold cho leave you chogether Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: She will be weary of me Sir, for I am weary of my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No ingeed Shir, ſhe chaksh great gelight in your dishcoursh, pray letch her have it Shir, I'll rechurn preſently, wheegle him, dee hear? wheegle him, you may get a good Legashy.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: He's gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: My Perriwigg and Love Aquipage, quickly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How now! what's this?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: An Adorer of yours fair creature, no unſound, falſe, wicked Florio, but a ſound, young, vigorous, paſſionate Lover, if you will not believe my tongue, believe my Noſe, the patch covers wholſome fleſh, believe my Leggs, which leap, vault, and run, except from you ſweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am betray'd! drawn into a Snare (but 'tis a ſweet one (aſide) help! help! help!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I need no help my Dear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But I do, help! help! help!
Oh 'tis a lovely Gentleman! (aſide.) help! help!
'Tis a delicate Gentleman! (aſide.) help! help!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why do you call ſo loud? I can help you to what you want.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Help, help! will you force me? (I can't reſiſt him, (aſide.) help! help!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: All this is to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh fie upon you, what a Man you are? A handſome Man I mean, (aſide.) I am out of breath with ſtriving, help! help! Oh my heart pants! help! help! help!

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT, the Third.
div.stage: Enter Artall and Lucinda; The scene continues.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: OH! Fie upon you! fie upon you, was ever vertuous Gentlewoman ſerv'd ſuch a trick before?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh! frequently, ſcores of 'em are ſerv'd ſo, every Eaſter- Term.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What, Women that are as vertuous as my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ay, full as vertuous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O Lord bleſs us! what a place is this! I did not think there had been ſuch a place, nor ſuch a Man as you in the world, I ſhall never endure to ſee you more.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, never as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You'l change your mind.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Never whilſt I breath.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes when I come next, mean while I am your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your Servant dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: When shall I wait on you again, Madam?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When you pleaſe Sir, I shall at all times be glad of your good Company.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your Servant dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your Servant dear Sir.

div.stage: Enter Bartoline and his Clerk with Papers.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Wher'sh my Wife, and poo Mishte Florio? huh! where are yey?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Here's your Wife, but poor Mr. Florio is gone away very ill.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Were you not weary of him? huh!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No indeed, I cou'd have been with him all day and all night.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I doubt you dishemble.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed I do not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I doubch you had rather been at a Play, or shome other Diverchishment.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſwear I had more pleaſure from him, then ever I had from any Divertiſement in my life.

sp.speaker: Bar.
