sp.p: Well, be good whilsht I live, 'twill be the betcher for you when I dye, then I shall leave you Rich enough cho chake your choish of young handshome Coxshcombes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do not tell me of young handſome Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You won't Marry I warrant when I am gead? no not you? a 'houſand to one, you will be Married before, nay, I dare hold chenne pound you are Conchracted now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Nay, not by a Preiſh, but by looksh, and shmirkeh, &c. twiſching of Eye-beamsh, and making a Wedging-Ring of the fine round
mou'h—and yuſh, I believe you have promiſh'd your ſhelfe cho a 'houſand foolſh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You wrong me extreamly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: All ye betcher, I'm ſhure I ſhall diſherve your kindneſſe, for I am labring cho make you a rich Widgow; The Tearme won't laſht a mouth, and I ha' more breviatſh and Papersh putch incho my hand shince I went out, yen I can read in 'hree monh'sh, I'm shure on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And what muſt become o' your Clyents Cauſes?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I yont care, I know what will become o' yeir Money; I'le lock it up preshently, all for you, gi' me my Papersh, come let me shee now—let me shee—whatsh her cho do?[Reads his Papers. Oh! among other 'hingsh heresh a buy shnesh in which my Brothersh Neck'sh conshern'd; He ish 'hirchy years younger yen I am, yet he ish old enough cho be Wiſer; He hath play'd de foole and killg a man, and ye Widow bringsh an Appeale, in which it sheemsh yere arishesh matcher of Law—my Brother shendsh me chenne poun' cho rechaine me, ye Widow shendsh me twenchy, sho I follow ye poore Widyowsh buyshnesh, I am for ye poore Widow, I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you Hang your Brother for ten pound?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You shou'd ashke me if I wou'd hang him for chenne shillingsh, yen I might conshiger it, but chenne ponn' ish a great yeale o' money, tish a great yeale of money, come let me shee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis a little againſt the Law of Nature.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ye Law of Natchure belongsh cho Pchivilians Woman, we comon Lawyeash y'ont ſtudgy ye Law of Nachure, tish none of our shtudgy—no—no—But come let me shee—whatsh here now? come.

div.stage: Bartoline Reads, Drums beat without; Enter Podeſta, Brick-layer, and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's your bus'neſs Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I have a Meſſage to you Lordship, from his Highneſs the Vice-Roy.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Very well Sir, I attend.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: His Highneſs deſires your Lordship not to diſturb and frighten the City, by raiſing the Town Forces to no purpoſe

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He is of opinion, 'tis to no purpoſe, is he?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I am of a contrary opinion, and I am ſeldome miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: His Highneſs bid me tell you, that for the bare ſatisfaction of the Poeple, (though danger requires it not) he is willing you ſhou'd keep up half you do.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He wou'd have me keep but half?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Then I will keep as many more.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Is that your Anſwer?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Yes, and we will juſtifie it by Law.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well bred, good humour'd Gentlemen theſe, and fine Subjects

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He ſhall ſhortly hear from us things that [Exit Gent. will vex him worſe then this, Articles that may coſt him his Employment. We'l not onely humbly humbly addreſs to His Majeſty, but Impeach him; I'll teach him not to Knight me.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Here is Counſellour Bartoline, the greateſt Lawyer in the Kingdome, and one of our own Party, you can't poſſibly adviſe with a better Man about 'em, give him the Hundred pound Fee, the City allows you to retain ſome eminent Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I will, Counſellour Bartoline, I muſt ſpeak a word wi' you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'm not at leiſhure, I have Caushesh cho look over, yat are cho come on cho Morrow.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: But we have a Cauſe in which the whole City's concern'd.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You muſt deferr it yen, for if I y'ont appear in yish Cauſe cho Morrow, 'twill be losht, it wholly dependsh upon me, and I cannot but in conshiensh atchend it, I have a Fiftshe pound Fee.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: We'l give you a Hundred pound, Mun.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: How? a Hundger'd poun? huh?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay, there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here, lay ashide yesh Papers,
Well, whatsh your buyshnesh now—come—huh!

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: We are drawing up Articles againſt the Man of the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yea Man at ye Cashtle, wosh yat?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He means the Vice-Roy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Archiclsh againſt the Viceh-Roy—huh?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Gi me ye Papersh again, I won't meggle in't.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: How! not meddle?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No, I won't meggle, I won't meggle.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I may loosh my Head mun, I won't meggle, no, no, come let me she.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: No matter if you do looſe your Head, if you have no more honeſty nor love for your Country, then to refuſe to do your Countreys bus'neſs, when you have received your Countreys Money.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I yon't care whosh money 'tish, let it be ye Devilsh money I'll keep it, now I have it, but I won't meggle in the buyshnesh—no— no—come—come.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Keep our Money? and not do our bus'neſs?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Tish our way. 'Tish our way.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, by your Favour, either do our bus'neſs, or pay back our Fee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Pay back your Fee—'twash never known mun, and I won't shet an ill pregident; no, no, tish shufficient I won't be againſt you, yatsh enough. Come let me shee.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Did one ever know ſuch a Knave? what ſhall we do? for you and I muſt account for this Money.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Let me alone with him, I underſtand Mankind; Counſellour Bartoline, do not play the Fool wi' your ſelf, and looſe a Thouſand pound, which you may get by this Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A 'houshand Pound? huh!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, this is a great Cauſe, and the City will go through with it, whatever it coſts 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Come, I'll underchake ye buyshnesh—come.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Did not I tell you I underſtand Mankind?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But I won't appea publiquely—dee hear—I won't appea.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Give us Councels will do the Man at the Caſtle's bus'neſs, and we don't care.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Counſellour Bartoline a word wi' you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Your buyshnesh.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I am ſent to you by his Highneſs the Vice-Roy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hish Highnesh the Vy'sh-Roy? shpeak shoftly.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: His Highneſs is enform'd you are here, and very great with theſe Men.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I great with yesh Men? 'tish falsh, they're Knavsh, I haitch 'em, I haitch 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p:
Nay, he believes you onely aſſiſt 'em as a Lawyer for your
• ees, you have too much Wiſdom and Law to engage in their ill and dangerous deſigns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hang 'em, hang 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: And ſuch they have, his Highneſs is well aſſur'd.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No doubeh on't, mosht sherchain.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: And therefore he's reſolv'd to puniſh 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He musht do't! he musht.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: To that end he intends to indict 'em of ſeveral Crimes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: How far they will extend in Law he knows not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Very probable.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Therefore he ſends you by me a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He doesh very well—very well—hesh a wysh Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: For your Advice.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'll give it him, but not publiquely—I won't appea, but I'll give him shuch advysh ash shall do yeir buyshn • sh.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I'll tell it him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If he hash a fanshy cho hang'em he shall.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I'll tell him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Well, you'l undertake our bus'neſs?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Let me alone—give me your Articlesh—come—now I'll go ſtudgy, come along.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: So, this is a notable old Fellow, if he undertakes the bus'neſs, he l do't.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You need not inform me in Mankind.

div.stage: Enter Florio wrapt in a Cloak, leaning on a Staff, led by Pietro.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Where's my—Where's my—every little thing puts me ſo out of breath—Where's my Lord Podeſta?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Here Mr. Florio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have great (pooh) blows) I am ſo faint with every little motion, and little talk—I have great News for you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Great News, and I not know it? there is ſeldome any thing to be known that I don't know.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I • ll tell it you, but I muſt open a Vein firſt that I may breath—
• e • ch a Surgeon—I play'd the Fool—uh! as I came—uh! along, I ſaw a young Woman with naked (pooh) Breaſts—going I'm certain to—pooh—to be naught; • o I reprov'd her, but ſhe was very angry, and ſed ſhe was an honeſt Woman; then I ſed ſhe was to blame
to let thoſe two Breaſts come abroad, like two Domeſtick Intelligences to ſlander her; ſo ſhe ſaid ſhe did it to pleaſe her—pooh—her Husband; ſo I ſed her Husband was a wiſe Man to make his Wife ſhew her—pooh —her Breaſts in ſuch a Town as this, ſuch Treaſure wou'd invite Pickpockets enough to rob him of it. And thus with this wanton Woman I waſted my—pooh—my Spirits.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: So you have done now more then needs, you might have told us the News in the time you have told the Story.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed—Well, I'll tell you the News, you may ſee how things go, for my part I am glad I have not long to live, to ſee the Nation Ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Why what's the bus'neſs?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: There's a French Fleet upon the Coaſt, and ſix of the principal Commanders lurk in the Diſguiſe of Pilgrims about Mount Veſuvio, to burn the Town by night, and let in their Friends.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I knew all this ſeveral Hours ago.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is it poſſible my Lord? you have excellent Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: So I have.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm ſure 'tis not half an Hour ſince I invented it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What do you think made me raiſe the Militia?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Was it for that?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Do you think I rais'd 'em for nothing, I never do a fooliſh thing.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And why wou'd you not tell me?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I had ſome reaſons of State.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And what will your Lordſhip do in it?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What elſe, but ſeize 'em?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: We muſt do it very privately, leaſt they ha' notice, for they have Friends in Town.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You need not teach me my bus'neſs, nor that they have Friends in Town, what meant the Order to put down Two Regiments o' the Militia?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Was there ſuch an Order?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I was an ear-Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You may ſee how things go: whereupon I ſmartly replyed, Wou'd they have Two down, ſaid I? then I will have four more up, ſaid I, ſmartly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That was very well.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: As well as I cou'd have advis'd.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, I know what I do.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I proteſt I thought you had done it onely to croſs 'em.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, I have deeper fetches in things then you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I ſee you have.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Now you ſhall ſee how I'll mannage this bus'neſs, I will leave my Hat, Gown, and Perriwig here, put on your Hat, Coat, and Perriwig Bricklayer, and go out ſo diſguis'd, that my own Family ſhall not know what is become of me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That will do very well.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I cannot adviſe better.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Then I'll go to your Houſe Bricklayer, and there ſend for Twenty Men ſuch as I can truſt, and Arm them, and when that's done I won't truſt them neither, but take 'em along, and they themſelves ſhall not know whether they go, What ſay you to this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Incomparable.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Very well; but why wou'd you not do this before, ſince you had intelligence of theſe Men?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: For good reaſons you may be ſure, I never do a fooliſh thing; come, give me your things.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What ſhall I wear my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Any Porters ſo far as your Houſe,
Now will not this deal with Pilgrims?

sp.speaker: Mr. Florio,
sp.p: have you ſtrength to go with us?

div.stage: Arm'd with a Blunderbuſs at his back.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: To mount Veſuvio? I may as well hope to carry the Mountain on my back, but if I had ſtrength I durſt not venture.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Why, what are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pride, Pride, I am mighty apt to be vain, formerly a little ſucceſs in a Jeſt or a Song, or Libell, wou'd ha' made me a notorious Aſs; imagine then, if when I come from this great expedition, I ſhou'd ſee my name in every Intelligence, my Picture on every Wall, what an inſufferable haughty Coxcomb I ſhou'd be? Lord, Lord, I ſhou'd be ſo proud!

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: For my part now, I go o' purpoſe for theſe things, and intend to ſit for my Picture as ſoon as ever I come home, I was bid Money for my Face yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You who have but one infirmity, need not fear it. But my Vices like Tories ride in troops, and if one gets into me, a hundred will follow: if now I am ſick I ſhou'd love your praiſes, when I am well I ſhall love your Wives.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He ſpeaks a great deal of reaſon, we'l go without him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: But who ſhall guide us?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord needs no Guide.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
No, I know where they are to a hairs breadth, Here comes my Wife, don't let her know who I am; [Enter Roſaur •
I remember I read in Plutarchus, that Brutus wou'd not truſt his Wife Portia with Affairs of State, I'll imitate his Politiques.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: No News o' my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Madam he's buſied about ſome great affair.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Mr. Florio, I have an humble addreſs to make to you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is it good Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
I am a Woman more nice and careful of my honour, then any other Woman is of her face or skin; in my Husbands preſence I am ſecure from malice, but in his abſence I can never open my doors but ſlander will enter,
even your Religion and Vertue Sir cannot hinder her from following you in, and faſtening on us both.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Slander will have lean food in me Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: All's one Sir, 'tis beſt to avoid her. I would therefore humbly beg you at all times of my Husbands abſence to beſtow your excellent converſation elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Twill be very prudent Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I hope you'l not take it ill Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: By no means Madam.
Do you hear what an excellent Wife you have?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I know her Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: An Admirable Woman!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, you need not inform me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Who ha' you got wi' you there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A very Honeſt Man Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Are you ſure o' that? 'cauſe theſe are dark times, a Knave will ſhine in 'em like rotten Wood by night, And that Man has a notable out-ſide, he reſembles much my Husband, who is one of the wiſeſt men in this Age.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe is a Woman of vaſt parts.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I have a great fancy to ſecure him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Pſhaw, we ſhall have a fiddle faddle with her, and ſpoil our buſineſs— Get you gone, go.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: How does he flye? that's ſuſpicious. Seize him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Away, away Man, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No good Madam, I'll be bound for him. Ha! Ha! what a Coxcomb is this? now is he gone he knows not whether, to catch he knows not whom.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What an Excellent thing, and how Uſeful in the World is Credulity?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, to many excellent Trades, To the ſparkiſh Fop, the Shopkeepers large faith ſwells his Feather and garniture, To the Polititian, the believing empty-headed Rabble are his Bladders. But oh 'tis of excellent uſe to a Lover.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And to a Trade you ha' not nam'd—a Swearer.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A Lover is a Swearer, a private one, he is not a publique Evidence, a Swearer-General.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You were once Swearer-General to our whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But I recant, and now will I kiſs no Book but theſe ſweet Lips.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Hold! not ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why, what's to do?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I muſt bluſh a while.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Bluſhes are for the Morning of Love, we have travelled many tedious hours ſince that, and without any refreſhment, except baiting now and
then at a Kiſs, Thoſe lips are delightful places, but not the end of the Journey.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You ſay you have travel'd in Love, you ſay true, you have paſſed through many hearts, and I fear have waſted all your love by the way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have onely tri • led away ſome unneceſſary travelling expences, here will I lay out my whole heart.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: A mortgag'd Heart!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Indeed it is not.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What ſecurity will you give me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Have I not Pawn'd a Kingdom to you, I was King of Libertines, and I have left my Dominions, and all my fair female ſubjects to be a ſlave to you and a fool to the Prieſts. [Knocks. Knocking! we're undone! have talk'd away our precious minutes, Heaven grant it be not the old Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Whoever it be, we are in an ill condition to [louder knocking. be thus lockt up together.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Venture to ask who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: 'Tis I Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: 'Tis the fool Craffy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What ſhall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Madam, I muſt ſpeak with your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Come ſome other time, I'm very buſie now.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: This buſineſs muſt be done now Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Diſpatch it where you are then.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I cannot, this is private buſineſs Madam.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Then you muſt let it alone, for I neither can nor will ſpeak wi' you.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: You muſt and ſhall ſpeak with me, ſince you go to that, and if you won't let me in at the Door, I'll climb in at the Window.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You are ſawcy Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: There is no buſineſs to be done without ſawcineſs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What ſhall we do with this Fellow?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Put on my Husbands Gown, Hat, and Perriwig, and lye upon the Couch as if you ſlept.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Will you let me in or no?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You are in great haſte Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Yes that I am, my buſineſs is earneſt.

div.stage: Florio is diſguis'd, and lies down, Roſaura opens the Door, Enter Craffy Drunk.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: So, ſhe's all alone, as I hope to be ſav'd!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Well, what's your buſineſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: I have ſweet buſineſs! delicate buſineſs, and I'll do't I'll Warrant me—Drunkenneſs has given me wit and impudence, if it don't dis • igure me, I don't care, I am curſedly afraid 'twill put my features out of Rank and File, they won't march even, and gracefully, and in Battalia.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Well, haſt thou given me all this trouble, and now haſt nothing to ſay?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſomething to ſay, and now it ſhall out. I come— I come—moſt ſweet—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Speak ſo • tly, for your Father's aſleep on the Couch.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: My Father there! the Devil take him for his pains, that Blo • khead never did me any good, nor ever will; now he lies like a great Boome to hinder my Veſſel from coming into the Harbour when the wind is fair: Od I could find in my heart to cut him!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Well Sir, you ha' no buſineſs it ſeems?

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Od I'll do my buſineſs, and let the old Fool diſpoſe his greaſie Bags as he has a mind; I care not, I'le paſs the Rubicon, and be ant Caſar, aut nullus— I come then to tell thee ſuch a ſtory, as no Age, nor Hiſtory, can do the like.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Ay, prithee let me hear that.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Ay, prithee let me hear that with a ſmile, many a Roman General has fought a Battle upon the encouragement of Birds that have not chirp'd half ſo prettily; Prithee let me hear that—And thou ſweet Rogue, thou ſha't—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: The Bruit is drunk, and I never diſcern'd it.

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: Then thou delicate Creature, I come to tell thee, I love and adore thee!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Love and adore me? what does the Coxcomb mean? but why ſhou'd I conſider the meaning of a Fool in drink?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Nay, my News does come wet out o' the Preſs, that's certain, 'tis delicate News, is't not? what ſay'ſt thou? Have I no Darts nor Arrows in my eye? prithee look upon me, nay, look if this Fantaſtick Woman will look upon me? prithee look upon me, I'm newly Shav'd, and a Man looks like a notable ſmirk Rogue when he's Shav'd, his face is like a Bowl new wip'd, he may kiſs the Miſtriſs if he has any skill, and I'll try.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Sirrah, attempt any R • deneſs to me, and I'll waken your Father, and ruine ye; I am amaz'd he ſhou'd ſleep thus!

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: I believe there is a Proclamation come out againſt ſleeping, and the Rogue takes a nap to affront the Government, for nothing elſe could make a Whigg quiet ſo long, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So Sir, you are a Ran • ing Tory, begone you had beſt, before I waken your Father, and you who are now ſo • ull o' Wine, be turn'd out o' doors, and want Bread, conſider that Sir.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: How! when I have thee before my eyes, doſt thou think I can conſider a Cruſt? what a pittiful hungry thought was there?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Diſ-inheriting then and ſtarving, are nothing to thee.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: I ſtarve now, Love has diſ-inherited my ſtomach, which, before I fell in love with thee, had as good a Title to meat as any ſtomach in Chriſtendom, that is, if meat be made for ſtomachs, and now if I were to go to Law with a Chicken for Crums, he'd Caſt me, I ſhou'd ha' nothing to ſhew for 'em, ſo that I muſt enjoy thee that I may eat agen.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
Enjoy me Sirrah! do you know who I am, you dare mention ſuch 〈◊〉
Word before me?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Know thee! I, well enough.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Am not I your Father's Wife Sir?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: And what of all that?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What of all that?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Thou think'ſt I warrant I'll be frightned with Inceſt? with fee, fa, fum, I am not a Child to be ſcar'd from a Sack-Poſſet with a white fheet, if we muſt meddle with nothing that is a Kin to us, we muſt not eat or drink, for we are all near a Kin to our Victuals, but thou art no Kin to me, thou art onely tack'd to my Father's ſide by a Prieſt, and art no more my Mother then his Back-Sword is, for that's buckled to his ſide ſometimes; Beſides, I don't know whether he be my Father or no, I'm ſure he is not fit for't.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Whatever I am to him or thee, 'tis ſufficient I am nearly related to Vertue and Honour, and do not dare Sirrah, ſo much as to talk undecently before me.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Why doſt thou talk undecently before me?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Who I?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Yes, thy eyes talk Bawdy, thou haſt the wanton'ſt eyes that ever I ſaw in my life: Gi' me a Kiſs, gi' me a Kiſs I ſay—the beſt you have in the houſe, won't you? I'll come to the Veſſel my ſelf then.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Bleſs me! Husband! Husband!

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Let him wake if he dares.

div.stage: Craff. chaces her round Chairs, Florio Snorts.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Oh Lord! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Ha! does he ſnort? let him ſnort agen, he has neither Powder nor Shot in his Noſe.

div.stage: Knocking at the door, Craffy starts, Roſaura opens it.

sp.speaker: Piet
sp.p: Oh Madam! your Husband and the Bricklayer.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: How! where are they?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Juſt coming into this Room.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Cannot your Maſter poſſibly get by?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Not poſſibly.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Oh miſery! ſhame! death! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: What's the matter Madam?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Ha! what comes into my head! I'll make this fool beat his Father out; (aſide) Oh your Father will be Murder'd, and I abus'd, here are Villains got into the houſe in Arms, one of them they ſay has a deſign upon my Perſon.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Your Perſon?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Ay, help us for Heavens ſake!

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Juſt coming into this Room, beat 'em out o' the houſe, as you value your Fathers life, and my Honour.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Here they come.

div.stage: Enter Podeſta and Bricklayer, with Muſquets and Blunderbuſſes at their backs, their Waſtes ſtu • k round with Pistols, Craffy knocks his Father down, Pietro gets down the Bricklayer, whilſt they are Scuffling Roſaura conveys Florio away, and lays the Hat, Gown, and Perriwigg upon the Couch, as if one ſlept under 'em; after ſome rowling upon the Stage, Podeſta gets Craffy undermoſt.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Some one help me to kill this unnatural Rogue.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: No, take him alive I charge you, that we may know who put him upon this horrible damnable Plot, for this is as horrible a Plot as has been theſe thouſand years.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sirrah, who put you upon this horrible wickedneſs?

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Sirrah, who put you upon the horrible wickedneſs of attempting this ſweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This Fellow's Drunk.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: As Drunk as he is, he asks no impertinent Queſtions, nor has he committed any great Error in the ill-favour'd Entertainment he has given you for entring my Husbands houſe in this armed poſture, in theſe dangerous times, without giving me any notice what he has done, he did by my command, and i'le juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This is a wiſe Woman.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: The Woman could not act wiſer if ſhe were my own Wife.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'le reveal my ſelf to her, Sweet-heart I am your Husband.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Come Sir, lay aſide your unſeaſonable and unmannerly mirth, theſe are no Rallying times, or if they were, you are not my equal at Repartee with me: But now I think on't, ſee what's become of my Husband ſome body, he has ſlept theſe two hours upon that Couch, and this rude Scuffle has frighted him away.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I fancy this is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, upon my Honour I left my Gown, Hat, and Perriwigg upon that Couch, and there's no difference between the Lord Podeſta and me but a Gown.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Then there is Roguery, for there lay a Fellow under that Gown. I'le ſwear I heard his Noſe go.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: He ſays true.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Bleſs me! here's a Plot.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Some of the French Pilgrims to Murder you, and burn your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Moſt certain, fetch a Regiment of the Militia, I'le have a Centry at every door in my Houſe, two at every Poſt of my Bed, and one under my Bolſter.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Search all the Tubbs, Pots, Bottles, and Veſſels in your Houſe, for Gun-powder.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, and I'le unpave the ſtreets to ſee if the Stones be not Hand-Granadoes.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: 'Tis neceſſary, and I hope your Lordſhip will not blame me for defending your Houſe, though you ſuffer'd ſomething by it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: 'Twas admirably done.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Wiſely, very wiſely.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Like a Woman that knows Man-kind.

sp.speaker: Craff.
sp.p: Well, and ſhall I no praiſes have, That beat the Knave?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: O 'twas very well done Craffy.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Very well indeed.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: But are not theſe Ʋnhappy times,
That I can take no Joy
In ſuch a Wife, and great Eſtate,

sp.speaker: Craf.
sp.p: And ſuch a Son as I.

div.head: SCENE a Garden.
div.stage: Enter Podeſta, Bricklayer, Captain of the Militia, and two Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: COme, Captain, place thoſe two Souldiers behind thoſe two Doors, and then my Houſe will be too hot for a Knave.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: For the juſtification of our Proceedings, we will print a Narrative of the Pilgrim under the Gown. As Paper, in Holland, paſſes for Money, Pamphlets with us paſs for Religion and Policy: a bit of Paper in Holland, from a Man of Credit, takes up Goods here, pays Debts there; ſo a Pamphlet will take up Fools here, make Fools there. A Pamphliteer is the beſt Fool-maker in the Nation. And this Story well improved—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: The Story's well enough, what need we lye to no purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: By your favour, 'twill be to good purpoſe; a Lye will give it the ſtamp of our Party. Lyes are the Supporters of our Arms, and the Great Seal of our Corporation.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: If a Lye will do the Nation any Service, I ſhall not ſcruple.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You wou'd ha' no Reaſon; for that Lye that does as much good as Truth, is as good as true; Ergo, 'tis true. Quicquid eſt idem, eſt idem, is a Rule in Logick, but you know no Logick.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: But I know a Rule in Divinity, that ſays, you are not to do Evil that Good may come thereby.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Ay, that Good may come, and not come: but the Evil that does Good, is a Good Evil; but no Evil is Good, Ergo, 'tis no Evil at all: But there's no talking Logick to you, you don't underſtand it.

div.stage: Enter a Man with Priſoners Basket, and Beggers.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How now, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Honour, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Speak to me, I am my Lord, that is, I manage all

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It has always been a Cuſtom for the new Lord Pod • ſt to ſend poor Priſoners ſome relief.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: It has been a Cuſtom you ſay?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Is there any Law for it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Law, Maſter?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Ay, for we will do nothing but according to Law.

sp.speaker: Alan.
sp.p: You wou'd not have poor Pris'ners ſtarve, Maſter

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Sir, if they ſtarve according to Law, no body has any thing to ſay.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That's hard, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Go, get you about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pray Maſter.

sp.speaker: 2 Begg.
sp.p: I hope, Maſter, you will be kinder to us, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Why, what are you?

sp.speaker: 2 Begg.
sp.p: Honeſt, poor People, Maſter, that always us'd to have ſome broken Meats from my Lord Podeſta's Table, and now we ha' not had one bit.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Is there any Law for it?

sp.speaker: 1 Begg.
sp.p: Law, Maſter?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Ay, for in plain Terms, we will do nothing for any body, that is not of our Party, but what we are forc'd to by Law.

sp.speaker: 1 Begg.
sp.p: We are all o' your Party, Maſter.

div.stage: All the Beggers, and Man with the Basket.

sp.p: Ay, Maſter, we are all Whiggs, Maſter, we are all Whiggs.

sp.speaker: 2 Begg.
sp.p: Maſter, I poll'd for you.

sp.speaker: 3 Begg.
sp.p: I poll'd three times over, for my Lord; came in three ſeveral Coats, and paſt for three men.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Say you ſo? who employ'd you?

sp.speaker: 3 Begg.
sp.p: The Doctor, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And ſeveral of our Priſoners poll'd for my Lord. Maſter.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, give 'em half-pence a piece.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Half-pence!—my Lord—half-pence!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, when my Year's out, I'le conſider farther.

sp.speaker: 1 Begg.
sp.p: We ſhall ſtarve in that time, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Go, go, begone, the Bricklayer and I are conſulting about Affairs of State, for the good of you all, how to ſecure your Religion and Property.

sp.speaker: 2 Begg.
sp.p: Our Property, Maſter?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Go, go, you ha' no Property, nor, I think, Religion, you are idle Knaves—begone.

sp.speaker: 1 Begg.
sp.p: The Devil take you—a half-penny Lord, is the Podeſta's place worth but a half-penny?

sp.speaker: 2 Begg.
sp.p: Plague rot you—a half-penny Lord, I'd ha' ſeen the Devil have you, before I'de ha' choſe you, if I had known.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A half penny Lord—confound 'em damn'd Rebel Rogues, I hope to ſee 'em hang'd.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Now let us to Counſellour Bartoline's Chamber, to know his Opinion, concerning our Arming and Fortifying.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: One Lawyer is poſitive againſt us.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: That's a Tory Fellow, I don't mind Tory Law.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: But he ſpoke a great deal of Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I care not a Farthing for Reaſon, Law, nor Scripture, if they ſide with the Tories. I prefer Whigg-Nonſence, before Tory-Reaſon: But come.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman; Bartoline and his Clark at a little diſtance after.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No body in the Houſe here? O Sir, you are the Man I deſire to ſpeak with. I ſuppoſe you remember me?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I remember you? How ſhou'd I remember all the People gat come cho me?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange you ſhou'd forget me, 'tis not long ſince I put juſt ſuch another Fee into your Hand, as this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Od ſha me! now you putch it incho my headge, I do remember you; you come from ye Viſh roy.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I do ſo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He iſh a worhy Genkleman, I ſhall be glad to ſherve him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: The Buſineſs is, My Lord Podeſta fortifies without his leave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Doeſh he? yen heſh a Yebel, ſhay I ſhay it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: But is there no Clauſe in their Charter will bear 'em out?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Shir, if yere be ſhuch a clauſh, 'twill overthrow yeir Charcher, 'twill argue the King was deſhieved, ſo his Grant will be void; 'tiſh againſt ye Peyogative, aſh I'le prove outch Common Law, and clea ſhatchute Law; and if I yon throw 'em on yeir backſh I'le hang for't, ſho chell ye Viſhroy—But I'le be privatſh.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I'le tell him.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: O, here he is! come, Counſellour, we muſt ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You muſht not, for I am very buiſhy.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: But theſe ten pieces muſt, and ſhall ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly, I have a great yeal o' buiſhneſh; but I have alſho a great kindneſh for boh you; for I hinke you are very honeſht Men, and wiſh well to ye Nation, and have very good yeſhignſh. And I will do you what kindneſh I can, I will ingeed. Well, come, your buiſhneſh—huh—

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: May the Subject—Subject? I don't love that word Subject: But, come, may the Subject Fortifie by Law, without leave?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: May he wear a Shword by hiſh ſhide without leave? a ſhimple Shtory.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: But a Lawyer told me the contrary.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Twaſh not ye Lawyer, 'twaſh hiſh Fee; and Fees will ſhay any hing.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He ſaid 'twas againſt clear Statutes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Yerſh no ſhuch hing aſh a clea Shtachute, hant we Law yerſh the penning of 'em, and do you hink we won't make work for our ſhelu'ſh? We hate a clea Shtachute, as a Houſebreaker yoeſh a clea Night, I ſhpeak againſt my own Profeſſion; for I'm an honeſht Fellow, I am worth but ſhix hou
• and a year, and I mightch ha' been worth twenchy, if I wou'd ha' been a Knave; but I love cho make a Conſcienſh of what I ſhay, and do, I do ingeed, ingeed I do.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: But we are told that 'tis ſo againſt Law, that if there ſhou'd be any ſuch Power in our Charter 'twould argue the King was deceiv'd, and overthrow the Charter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
If ſuch a Power in your Charcher ſhould overthrow it,
'twou'd argue the King had yeſhieved you, mum, and who dares ſhay yat? yerſh a chrick for you, yey chalk like Foolſh and Knavſh, yey don't know what yey ſhay, let me alone wi you buiſhneſh, dee hea? but privately, very privately. Come along, come.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This is a notable old Fellow.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I was of his Opinion.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: My Lord, will you continue thoſe Guards and Centries about your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sweet Heart, to ask my Wiſdom queſtions, is to queſtion my Wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
I confeſs, you have reaſon to ſtand upon your Guard: 'twere well the People knew it; and your Son Craffy has a Pen
• it for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He ſhall meddle no more with his Pen, it has almoſt mop'd him. I wou'd give five hundred pound he had never ſeen a Pen in's Life; but I will take him from it before he's too far gone, and enter him into buſineſs: Here he is Powder'd, a Feather in's Cap, and Chatechiſing [Enter Craffy. his Face in a Glaſs; but it does not make him one wiſe anſwer, the Boy is ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, this will do—This will do—Nature writ no good Hand when ſhe penn'd me, becauſe ſhe wrote after a damn'd Copy, the Fool my Father; but this will mend ſome Letters. This will take my Mother.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Craffy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Drunkenneſs, like a Hog in a Garden, rooted up my Flowers, but now the Tulips in my Face begin to lift up their Heads.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Craffy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: They do i' Faith.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Why don't you come?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Let him alone, all this is not his folly, but mine, who have let him take more Poetry than his Brains wou'd bear, and have ruin'd my Child; and though I ſay it, a delicate young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p:
I fancy he's turn'd Amorous Fopp, for he's broke out into
a Feather, and all thoſe Fooleries that trouble Love-ſick People.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Indeed his Feather ſays ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And I'le take the Feathers word.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Before mine? do not you teach me to know my own Boy, nor any thing. I'd give you a hundred pound I were an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You may have it cheaper.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I mean in this, that I miſtook the Boys Diſtemper. Lord, that I ſhould let him ſpoil himſelf!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I have a mind to know his Contemplations. I'le go towards him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ha. my delicate Mother-in-law? I'm ready for her: I'le charge her with Smiles, Wit, Impudence, Modeſty, Humility, all ſorts of Weapons. Firſt, with Humility upon my Knees. Moſt Sweet Dear—ha! my Father behind—That old Fool is always in my way—How ſhall I get from my Knees again! The Devil take him. Moſt ſweet dear, Madam, pray to Heaven to bleſs me—Pray, my Lord, pray to Heaven to bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Bleſs thee?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, to bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What o' this time o' day.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A Bleſſing will do a Man no hurt at any time o' day.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, the Lord bleſs thee, and deliver thee from Poetry, ſay I, it has utterly ſpoil'd thee: That ever I ſhould let this Fellow tamper with Poetry. I cou'd ha' made him—I don't know what—I cou'd ha' made him ſuch a States-Man, as theſe times cou'd not ha' produc'd. Theſe times, pitiful Fellows, the Statesmen o' theſe times were all ſtarv'd at Nurſe. Some of 'em were Foundlings, one found under a Rump, another was a Maggot in Engliſh Noll's Noſe. A pack of ſtrange Fellows they are all, in ſhort, Craffy—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Moſt ſweet Woman.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You ſhall never Write nor Read more; but be a Man of Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I mean—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Did you mind what I ſaid to you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No, Madam—yes, Madam,—Ay, my Lord, I mean.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, Madam—Ay, my Lord—Sirrah, where are your Brains?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Brains Madam—my Lord, I mean.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: In your Ink-Pot, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'm now anſwering the Meddal.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I thought as much, the Devil take thy Poetry. Sirrah, meddle with Pen and Ink more if you dare.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Who muſt anſwer theſe things then? There's ne're a man o' Wit of our Party, but my ſelf, and my things are diſcommended. I know ſeveral People don't like my Huſhai: That I intend to call my Poem, The Meddal Revers'd, Written by him who was not the Author of Huſhai, nor of any Pen writ of our ſide

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Come, Poetry be hang'd, and Proſe too.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Come, come, my Anſwer will be the beſt.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: A Flail—if I meet with the Author in a convenient Place, I'le give him an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes; and, Sirrah, you ſhall never meddle with Pen, Ink, nor Book more, but be a Man o'buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I ſhall be a pretty Man o' buſineſs, never Write nor Read.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sir, the greateſt Politicians of our times, never Write nor Read, as you may ſee by their Speeches.
Come, Sirrah, you have Wit enough, and Courage too, and we have Buſineſs, and Enemies to employ both, inſomuch I ſhall not dare to go to Bed to Night.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sha'n't you? Then I'le dare to go thither in your ſtead: I have ſhew'd my Mother my Wit, I never ſhew'd her my Skin yet. Ile tempt her with that.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'le have you in the Head of a Party, go to Mount Veſuvio.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'm reſolv'd to ſteal to her when ſhe's a Bed.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Get a Horſeback preſently, d'ee hear?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, in a rich Night Gown, Point de Venice Shirt, and Velvit Slippers.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How, a Horſe-back in this Equipage? Do you know I bid you get your Horſe?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, waſh'd from head to Foot in Roſe Water.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: This is mockery, give me a Cane.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Come, let him alone.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What's the matter? what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's the matter wi' your Brains, Sirrah? For when I come to one ſide of your Head, they ſhift o' tother, that you never mind what I ſay. Get you gone you Raſcal you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sweet Rogue, I'le be with thee at Night.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Wou'd the Devil had had this Fellows Poetry: A Gentleman may carry a little of it for an Ornament and Pleaſure, as a Lady carries an Orange in her hand, but to have a Fool carry a great Basket on his Head, like a Coſtardmonger; and break his Brains.

div.stage: Enter Florio panting, Pietro leading him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Clamb'ring up theſe Stairs, has almoſt ſpent me; I'm ready to tumble down dead.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Poor Man, how bad he is!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I wonder he's come abroad!.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: 'Tis pity, he's a pretty Fellow.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My good Lord, I beg your Pardon a thouſand times for the Liberty and Confidence I take in your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You are very welcome, good Mr. Florio.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You may believe my Lord, Sir, he's your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Your Servant, good Madam. Why truly, we ſick People take upon us a ſtrange Authority, I know not by what Commiſſion. I▪ think 'tis becauſe Sickneſs is Heavens Meſſenger, and when a Man is upon the Road in a Meſſengers Hands, all People give way, and I am riding Poſt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Where are you all? where are you all?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Who ſays there are no Plots?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: He that has a mind to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: As he ſhall be. He that will not believe in the Doctor, muſt expect no Salvation in this Life.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What's the Plot, good Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Only to cut your Husband's Throat, and all our Throats, that's all.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Oh, you ha ſtruck me dead, ſome help, I faint.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Good Creature, ſhe's ſwooning; who's there?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Your Lady ſwoons.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Carry her away, don't let us be troubled with Women.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Take her into the freſh Air, and give her ſome ſtrong Water; and, do you hear? bring me ſome privately.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Come, the Plot.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What do you think the Tory Rogues have done? they have met with our Paper of Aſſociation.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What care we for that?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Ay, but they have drawn up one among themſelves, in imitation of ours, caſt one in our own Mold, taken our own words, and diſcharge 'em upon us.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: The Devil!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: As you ſhall hear: We, the Loyal, &c. finding to the grief our Hearts, a certain ſort of People, conſiſting of Hobb • ſts, Atheiſts, Fanaticks, and Republicans, have for ſeveral years laſt paſt, purſued a pernicious Plot, to root out the true Religion, ſubvert our • aws and Liberties, and ſet up Arbitrary Power.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Well, and what of all this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray hear.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And it being notorious, that they have been highly encouraged by the countenance and protection given 'em by the Rabble, and by their expectations of the ſaid Rabble coming to the Government. It appears alſo to us, that for theſe Deſigns, Ignoramus Garriſons have been eſtabliſht among us, by whoſe aſſiance theſe Men have laid a Blockade before the Crown it ſelf, denying it all relief, unleſs 'twill own it ſelf a dependance upon them.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: All this is true, and we are not aſham'd of it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And we conſidering with heavy Hearts, how greatly the Reputation and Honeſty of the Kingdom hath been waſted, in maintaining the ſaid Garriſons: And finding the ſame Counſels, after exemplary Juſtice upon ſome of the Conſpirators, to be ſtill purſued with the utmoſt Devilliſh Malice, and deſire of Revenge, whereby his Majeſty is in continual hazard, to be deſtroyed, to make way for the ſaid Rabbles advancement to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Well, and what of all this?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Have patience.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: The whole Kingdom in ſuch caſe, being deſtitute of all ſecurity of their Religion, Laws, Eſtates, and Liberties: Sad experience in the Caſe, the Rump Committee of Safety, Nol and Dick in England: And Maſſianello here, having proved the wiſeſt Laws to be of little force to keep out Tyranny under no Prince, or no lawful Prince.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I wou'd we had 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: We have, therefore, ſeveral times endeavoured in a legal way, by Indictments, to bring the ſaid Criminalts to condigne Puniſhment; but being utterly rejected, and brought almoſt to deſpair, we bind our ſelves one to another, jointly and ſeverally, in the Bond of one Firm and Loyal Society, and Aſſociation: And do ſolemnly Vow, Promiſe, and Proteſt to demoliſh the ſaid Ignoramus Garriſons, which are kept up in and about this City, to the great Terrour and Amazement of all the good People in the Land.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And ſhall be in ſpight of 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And utterly deſtroy all that ſhall ſeek to ſet up the ſaid Rabble's pretended Title, or ſhall raiſe any War, Tumult, or Sedition in his behalf, or by his Command, as publick Enemies, to our Laws, King, Religion, and Country, and this on penalty of being eſteemed ſuch our ſelves. Witneſs our Hands.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Are there any Names to it?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Only Nick-Names to know one another by: As Loyal Domeſtick Abſalom, and Achitophel, Tory Coffee-houſe, Towzer, Heraclitus, and ſuch Names, forty thouſand.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Oh, we have ſix times their Number.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Pray hear the Poſtſcript: Perſons to be deſtroyed, Imprimis the Podeſta.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Am I to be Murder'd Imprimis? bloody Rogues.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Then the Doctor: And why after him, unmannerly Raſcals?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Why after me? Sure, good Doctor, you won't diſpute precedency with me.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: But I will, good Podeſta, with you, or any Man in Chriſtendom; what the Devil are you?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What am I?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Ay, if you compare your ſelf with me, you are a Fop.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Fop! You are an unmannerly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: How! ho! call one of my Men ſome body. Serv. Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Go bid the Arch-biſhop of Naples come to me, I'le make his Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Doctor, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He means, bid the Arch-biſhoprick of Naples come to him, but it won't come, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You are a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Call a Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, are you out of your Wits, to quarrel who ſhould be murder'd firſt? I need care for it as little as you, I ſhall loſe as few days; for ſhame reconcile, pray reconcile.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Then let him not play the Coxcomb, if the Pope diſparage me, I'd ſay he were a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Well, well, the Podeſta reſpects you, Doctor, give him your hand.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Give him my hand firſt? I'd ſcorn to do't if he were a Prince.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Then give him your hand, Podeſta.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well come, Mr. Panchy.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Mr. Panchy?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Doctor I mean, come Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Then come Podeſta.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So, this is well, now let us know whoſe Throat is to be cut next.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: The Bricklayers and yours: Cum multis aliis quae nunc preſcribere longum eſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Will they cut mine? They may ſpare their pains: well we had more need go to Prayers than Quarrel. Pray Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Pray, Fools Head! what ſhould we pray for? That's like your Papiſts, who think to keep off Devils with Holy Water, as if a Devil were like a Cat, he cou'd not endure to wet his Foot: Theſe Devils are beſt driven away with Fire-locks.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You are in the right, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm ſure our Cauſe is in the right.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: We have a hundred thouſand Men, and they are always in the right: Set me in the Head of ſuch a general Counſel, and I'le be Pope, the only infallible Judge.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay, and have what forms of Worſhip you will; when a Canons the Preacher, who dare ſhut up the Conventicle, and nothing opens and divides a Text like Gun-Powder.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Heaven turn theſe wicked Men, I love their Souls.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Heaven turn 'em, out of the Kingdom, for I love their Lands; that's my way of turning my Adverſaries; and I'le ſet 'em part o' their way to Night: I'le ſhove the whole Town againſt 'em that ſhall be my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'le go arm my ſelf, and then watch upon the Battlements.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'le go with you.

div.stage: [Exeunt Pod. Doct. Capt. of the Militia.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'le to my Devotions: That is to your Wife—if I knew where ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Not far off.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I might ha' gueſs'd it by the ſudden gaeyty of all things, the whole Face of Nature ſmil'd on her ſweet favourite.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Upon the ridiculous Cuckold, and his wiſe Companions, which you have finely fool'd; for was not this Paper yours, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What a Ghoſt every Shaddow appears to a guilty Conſcience: Therefore I had not beſt conſent to your Murder of my Honeſty, for I ſhall never ſleep for fear of the diſcovery; and you Men commonly boaſt of thoſe Murders, and caſt a brazen Image of the dead Creature in an impudent Libel.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If this be not privately buried, it ſhall be your own fault.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: It ſhall be yours, for I have provided a Chappel fit for the Work, this Garden-houſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Then will I be a ſecond Ner •
▪ I have put all my City in a Flame.
And now, with Harp in Hand, I will ſurvey
My burning Rome, and whilſt it burns I'le play.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Then Nero take thy Harp into thy Hand,
The tuneful Strings will follow thy Command:
Now equal Orpheus in thy Art Divine,
Make all things round thee Dance, with one ſweet touch of thine,

div.head: SCENE continues.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Come, pray come in, Sir, ingeed I love your Companey mighchily. Come, how isht wi' you, Shir?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Better and better, Sir, that is to ſay, worſe and worſe, nearer my end, which I hope will be the better for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, yer'sh no doubt on't, Shir, you're a very good young Genkleman.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Not ſo good, as I ha' been bad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Tish no great matcher, Shir, we have all been bad; one chime or anoyer.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Not ſo bad as I, Sir, the Devil is not, cannot be ſo bad as I, he cannot drink, can he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why chruly, Sir, I believe notch, I yont know what he can goo, I yont chrouble my ſelf much wid him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I was one of the Devil's Low-Countries, always under a Flood: the Devil cannot Whore, Sir, neither, can he?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I yont know, Shir, in chroth, but I believe in general heisha great Rashcal.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I have not only debauch'd Women, but the whole Age, poyſon'd all its Morals, murder'd thouſands o' young Conſciences, ſung others aſleep, pump'd others with Drunkenneſs, Sin I Honour'd and Priviledg'd as a Peer to the Devil, Heaven I affronted, Libell'd his Court, and in my drunken Altitudes have endeavour'd to ſcour the whole Creation of Souls and Spirits, now is it fit I ſhou'd be ſav'd?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, why not, Shir, yo'nt chrouble your shelf wi' yosh mattchersh.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I doubt I trouble you, Sir, with my tedious Diſcourſes?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh no Shir ye'y are ve'y goodg ingeed: I never heardg a Parshon chalk sho well in a Pulpet, and I hear 'em shomechimes.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Don't you go always to Church, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yesh, Shir, but we Law yesh are sho employ'd all th, Week, y'at we may be excush'd if we chake a Nap a Shunday at a Shermon.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You ſhould not neglect the buſineſs of your Soul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No chruly, Shir, but we have a great yeale of buſineſs, a great yeale of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I do believe ſo, Sir, therefore I don't know how I can with any Confidence beg the favour of you to be one of my Executors.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O yesh shir, I'le find a chime for yat I wayant you, pray employ me, Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Thank you, good Sir, I will endeavour to reward your trouble.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
O good Shir, what you pleash, I shall be glad of any
• hoken of you love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I have drawn up ſome Heads of a Will.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You have y'one mighchy wishly, Shir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Will you pleaſe to look over it, Sir, as alſo ſome deeds of my Eſtate, whilſt I lay me down? For I am very faint: Shall I borrow your Bed, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Heart, Shir, Luſhenda, Girl.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Husband.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why gee come wi'out a Godly Book in your Hand, when you know how hesh inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ha' none, you muſt lend me one out of your Study.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I ha' none in my Shtudy, ne've hadg one in my Life, we Lawyesh yead no Yivinichy—Buy one [Aſide.] Come chake yish poo Genkleman, and lay him upon our Bedg, and cover him warm, and shit by him, and gee hear, chalke Goly to him; hesh making his Will, you yont know how you may win upon him.
Pray Shir go in, and I'le go cho my Shtudy, and come chee in a minute.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Pox o' thy haſte, [Aſide. I'm in no haſte, Sir, take your time.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No, no, I won't shtay shir, but pray let me lead you, for you are very weak.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh, no Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Pray Shir, let me.

div.stage: Exit. Art. led by Bar. and Luc.

div.head: SCENE continues:

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What new Larum's this? And I'm enquir'd after to be made an Aſs on; and ſent on ſome ſilly Errant, and ſo shan't come at my Mother to Night: Pox, I'le ha' none o' theſe Fooliſh doings: I'le get out o'the way; and now I think on't, I'le hide my ſelf in this Room; how now, the Doors shut, there's ſomebody in the Room ſure. I'le peep—I'm shot—I'm shot— I'm shot—

div.stage: Enter Podeſta, Doctor, Captain of the Militia, Souldiers, Bricklayer firſt.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What's the matter? what's the matter? what's the News?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'm shot, I'm shot, I'm shot.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Guard, Guard, Guard, Train-bands, Podeſta, Podeſta, come hither all quickly.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Bleſs us, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Your Son's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My Son kill'd?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'm shot—I'm shot—I'm shot.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh, where, where, where, poor Child—poor Boy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To the very Soul, to the very Soul.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh my poor Boy, my poor Boy! who shot thee, and where are the Murderers?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Who should, but the Aſſociating Bully Tories.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Aſſociators, Aſſociators.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Dr. Br. Oh, Rogues, Villains!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Whore and a Raſcal are Aſſociated in that Room, I mean your Wife and Florio are there joyn'd in one cloſe abominable Bond of lewdneſs, and Cuckold you, as if they were to be hang'd if they did not diſpatch it in a minute; the ſight has shot me to my Soul, my Soul.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How, Sirrah, have you invented ſuch a notorious Sham as this, to ſet me at variance with my Wife, and my Friend? and to buzz me wi' Domeſtick Confuſions, that I might not ha' my Brains at liberty, for the publick? Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are a Traytorly Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'll call you as much out of your Name, Sirrah, you are a Doctor of Divinity.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are an Aſſociating Tory.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are an Hermaphrodite, Compounded of to Sexes, Verſe and Proſe, and engender with neither.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Sirrah, I make better Verſes than your ſelf: and Verſes is all that you are good for: I make Officers and Jurymen, And Evidences, and Pictures, and Poppetts, and as good Verſes as you into the bargain. I made your Father what he is. That you are an ungrateful Fellow to be thus ſaucy with me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, you are a notorious Parricide, and plot with Traytors againſt your Own Father.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Father you are an abominable Cuckold, and plot with him that makes you one, againſt your Own Son: I will ſwear Fl • rio is in that Room aboard your Veſſel and ſtealing all your Cuſtoms: And here you ſtand upon the Key and let him.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I will break open the door to shew thou art a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Are you mad. Is not this a plain Sham Plot? here are either Traytors or Treaſonable Papers, and they will be found and laid to your charge.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You ſpeak with a great deal of Prudence; And I'll guard the door with my life, for my Honour is Concern'd.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your honour is concern'd, for you're made a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: The Honour of my Loyalty is Concern'd; for Sirrah you would make a Traytor of me: that you might hang me and get my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will call a Guard. Break open the door, and shew that you are a Cuckold, the Doctor Bricklayer, a Couple of Pimps. And I ſee a Guard go by: Guard, Guard, Guard! Treaſon, Treaſon, Treaſon!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nay then Militia, Militia, Militia, keep this door here, Treaſon, Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why who the Devil's able to bear this. Give me a P • ke I'le force my way in.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nay then Give me a Pike.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh Cuckold, Cuckold; Wittal, Wittal.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh unnatural Monſter!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Villain.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Tory.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
Hold Gentlemen, I have conſidered of it: Becauſe this Fellow is ſo inſolent; and potſiive and may report the worl ••
hinder Truth from coming to light, to clear the Honour of my ſelf, my Wife, and my Friend, I will open the door in the preſence of you all, and you ſhall ſee what's there: And ſo Gentlemen all bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You ſhall not open the door.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He ſhall—Break Open the door.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Break open the door.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What are you all madg? are we in Beglam here? you a Magiſhchrate, and ſhuffer ſhuch diſhorgerſh as yeſh in you houſh, you may be aſham'd: if you ha' no yegard cho your own cregit, ha ſhome pitchy on a poo Genkleman almoſt murger'd by the Noiſh you make. your own friend Miſhe Florio.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Florio! why where is he?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Upon my bedg, giving up the Ghosht.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: So Sirrah, and you ſay he is in this room.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Giveing up the Ghoſt upon that old Follo'ws Bed?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Now the ſham-plot's plain.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then he has given up the Ghoſt, and I ſaw his Ghoſt in this Room.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: And has Wife given up the Ghoſt too, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I don't know, but if they were Ghoſts, they were the lewdeſt Ghoſts that ever I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Come, Sirrah, confeſs your Rogueries.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Rogueries? Is it Treaſon to be mad? If he be there, my Wits are not here; I'm crack'd, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sho, ſhcolding again? I ſhuppoſe he'll conſhiger your Shivilitiesh in hish Will, which he's now a making.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: So, Sir, we ſhall looſe all our Legacies through your Roguery; come ask him pardon on your Knees.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I'm cruel afraid he'l dye before we come; let's go quickly, quickly.

div.stage: Florio and Roſaura coming out of the Room where they were hid.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ha! gone! this was good Fortune, away to thy Chamber, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And do you go home.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Pox on't, my pretty Opportunity is caſt away in a Storm; I muſt make t'other Voyage: I venture boldly into the Dominion of theſe Arbitrary Rogues, who have a ſtrange abſolute Authority over their own Conſciences, in Lying and Swearing: But Love, Love, Love.

div.stage: Enter Podeſta, Bricklayer, Doctor, Crafty, Barroline, Lucinda, Militia.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Gone away in diſhconchent?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, but in great pain, he ſaid his Head was torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall be no looſher, he knowſh 'twaſh not my fault. Come away Girl.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p:
Now I'le ſee what's in this Houſe; Fellow Souldier •
Guard me in, and have a care o' me.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
My Lord, my Lady's extreamly diſcompos'd with the fright ſhe had about your Lordſhip, and begs there may no •
be ſo much noiſe, it almoſt kills her.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Poor kind Heart, where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: In her Chamber upon her Bed.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: So, Sir, and you ſaid ſhe was in this Room.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Well, I'm mad, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Tell her there ſhall be no noiſe made.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: There's nothing in this Room.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What do you ſay to this, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That thou art an Aſs to talk to a Madman, for my Wits ha' given me the ſlip all o'th' ſuddain; I don't know how, nor which way.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Truly I'm convinc'd he ſays true, and my Hearts ready to break.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I am partly o' that mind; for in the Room is no ſign of a Sham-plot.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He does look wildly, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: He's mad, he's mad, and I ha' loſt my Child, my dear child, my poor Child.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Well, well, poor Father, don't take on ſo, my Wits are not gone far, they 'l come again, I warrant 'em, for I don't know who the Devil will entertain 'em, they were mad ſort o' Wits, and they are as mad that entertain a Poets Wits.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh curſe, curſe on Poetry, that ever I ſhould let thee meddle with it, my poor Boy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Father don't take on thus, thou'lt make me cry too.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I am ſo griev'd, that I will eat and drink and ſleep, and never mind what becomes o' the World.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Fy, fy, you won't be ſo wicked as that.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Wherefore ſhould I trouble my ſelf, when I have no body to inherit my Labours?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You ha' Friends enow, the Doctor, and I another.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Puh, a Child's above all: don't we ſee old Polititians venture their Necks for half a Child, a Changeling? And I have loſt a Boy worth millions, millions; and ſo I'le enjoy my ſelf 'till my Heart breaks, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Come, come, leave off this.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: No, I remember a ſaying of a Wiſe man:
Who plays the Knave t' enrich his Son, a Fool,
Is like a Fox that ventures for a Prey,
To bury it in ſome poor dirty hole,
And feed an Idle Dog, that trots that way:
The Beaſt is torn with fruitleſs pain and care,
And hang'd at laſt to make his Foe his Heir.
I ſhall play the Knave, and be hang'd for a mad Son, and ſo have a Tory; beg my Eſtate, No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Let's after him, and get him out of this humour.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I Am ſtrangely taken with this ſweet young Creature, 'tis ſo pleaſant to drink at ſuch a freſh Spring, which never Brute de •• l'd, or muddied: This old Fellow is but a wither'd Tree, that ſhades it; 'tis ſo much wholeſomer to love then the ſophiiſtcated Beauties o' this Town, which ſicken and kill an Intrigue in few days. Ha! where's my Gown and Cap •• I came in ſuch amorous haſte, I forgot my ſick dreſs, and I ſhall never be able to act my ſick part without it; • ut I ha' no patience to go back for't now— Here ſhe comes! My Dear! where's the old Devil that wou'd hinder our happineſs? Old Tempter I [Enter Lucinda will not call him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will not tell you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But you do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That he's abroad, your Smiles ſay it; thoſe Birds wou'd be gone, if that Winter were here. They ſay he won't come home a great while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are a Witch I think

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: We'l loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fye! Fye! you muſt not do ſuch things as theſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: O Sir! here's a Gentleman kiſſing my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh dear, my Husband!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sirrah, you lye; unſay't again, or you are a dead Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
No, no, Sir you did not indeed Sir, I miſtook, this is
the ſick Gentleman, Mr. Florio.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: How? a ſhick man kiſh my Wife?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No, no, I am not the ſick man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What are you, yen? call ſhomebody; cho sheize the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am the ſick man—I don't know what am, a pox.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yesh, yeſh, I know what you are, a Raſchcal; and you choo have abu'sd mee, a yamn'd Rogue and Shlut.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No, no Sir—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why do you geny your ſhelf yen?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sir, I was afraid you might be jealous, becauſe I was whiſpering in your Ladies Ear, my Lungs being weak.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Your Lungsh weak, and huff, and rant like a Bully▪ ah! you are Rogue.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That was only a ſudden blaſt of Zeal for your good Ladies reputation and mine, 'twill ſhorten my dayes. I ha'n't above a Month to live, and I have ſpent a fortnight's Breath before hand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Oh you Rashcal! have I ca • ch'd you in your chrickſh •
ha' you ſherv'd mee ſhuſh.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why do you cenſure ſo raſhly? I appeal to your Lat dy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Make a partchy Judge? no you have put choo goodg a Fee in you hand, cho let her bechray your Cauſh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You wrong me extreamly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I wrong'd my ſhell, cho entcher incho Bondsh of Marriage, and cou'd not perform Covenantsh, I might well hinke you wou'd chake the for • eychure of the Bond, and I never found equichy in a Bedg in my Life: But I'le trounce you boh, I have pav'd Jaylſh wi' the Boneſh of honeſter People yen you are, yat neve' did me nor any Man any wrong, but had Law o' yeir ſhydſh, and right o' yeir ſhydſh, but cauſe yey had not me o' yeir ſhydſh, I ha beggar'd 'em, 'hrown 'em in Jaylſh, and got yeir Eſ • chatſh for my Clyentſh, yat had no more chytle to 'em yen Dogſh.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And were you a good Man in that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I waſh a good Lawyer, and sho you ſhall find cho your cosht, we' in yish twelvemonth you ſhall not be worth a groatch.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh, I have too good a Title to what I have.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Chytle? I value not your Chytle: Beggarſh ha' not ſho many chrickſh, cho make ſhorſh in yeir Bodyeſh, aſh we have cho make 'em in Chytleſh. But I'le chell you what, I'le draw you up an exshellent Chytle cho the Jayl; and if you have any Children, I'le ſhettle it upon you and your Heirſh for ever; a Jayl ſhall be the Sheat of your Family. Od ſha' me, if any briſhke Rogue wou'd cut hiſh 'Hroat neatley, and privateley, yat nothing might appear againſt him but Shircumſhanſeſh, I'd bring him off, proviged it be not a ſhimple Rogue, yat wantſh Money.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: At this rate, your Wife ſhall be never the better for the Settlement you have made upon her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No, no more than I am the betcher for the Shettlement the Priesht hash made of her upon me, the Devil chake him for hish painsh, wou'd I cou'd find a ſlaw in't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Now thou makeſt me angry, thou ungrateful Knave •
ſuppoſe she and I have ſinn'd, haſt thou got an Eſtate in the Devil's Service, and wou'dſt thou hinder his work.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh! you impugent Whoremashcher!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sirrah, you have made more Whores than ever I did.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I make Whorsh?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes, thou haſt debauch'd whole Families by beggaring 'em, made Father and Mothers Bawds to their own Daughters, to earn that Bread thou haſt cheated 'em off.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You lye, you lye; but if I have, I only follow'd my chrade.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Well, and it may be my Trade is Whoring, and I'le follow that▪

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Follow it wi' your own Commoditchyesh then, and don't meggle wi' mine.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No more I ha' not, your Clerk is a lying Fellow, and your Lady a vertuous young Woman▪ and my near Kinſwoman; and ſince you abuſe her, I'le take her into my protection: Come, Couſin—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh brave Rogue! he chaksh away my Wife before my Faysh: Shirrah, I'le ha' forty Actionsh on you back preshently.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Then in a little time will I have forty Swords at your Throat, French Swords, I'le let in the Enemy, and cut the Throats of ſuch Rogues as you, who abuſe your Trade, and like ſo many Padders, make all People deliver their Purſe, that
ride in the Road of Juſtice. Better be rul'd by the Swords of gallant Men, than the Mercinary Tougues of ſuch Raſcals as you are.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Bear witnesh, Chreashon, Chreashon, horrible Chreashon.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I defy thee, do thy worſt; I am Florio, Prince of Whigs, never without a choſen Life-guard of Jury-men, with brazen Conſciences, proof againſt Oaths, like Bucklers againſt Arrows. So, come away, Couſin—Now will this Rogue fall on Florio.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh impugent yamn'd Rogue; Shirrah, be ſure you yemember all yish Chreashon, ha' you a good memory?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I mean a ferchile memory, will a 'hing grow in it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le remember enough to hang Florio, I'le warrant him I'le remember all he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And more choo. And becaush the Rogue runsh away wi' my Wife, he'l ſhay, I proshecute him out o' Malish; sho if no Body ſwearesh againſt him, but you and I, the Rashcal may come off: yerefore we musht look out for an Evidensh or choo more. Go cho shome able Atchurney, they are acquainched with 'em all, I'le look out for shome my shelf, and run my for Lord Chief Jushchishesh Warrant, cho apprehend yish Rash • all Go quickly, quickly.

div.head: SCENE continues.
div.stage: Enter Podeſta, Roſaura, Florio, Doctor, Bricklayer.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Impudent, lying, perjur'd Villain, accuſe me of being a ſecret Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And me of being your Gallant? I'm in a ſine condition to be a Gallant to a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: All's one, Malice will believe it, and I, though innocent, shall live in reproach

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not long, Madam, not above a Week; my Doctor has confeſs'd to me, I shall dye ſome day next Week, and then I ſuppoſe this Story will dye too.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How! are you to dye next Week?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, a great Lady will call for me, the only Lady in the World, I have an Intrigue withall.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The Moon, my Lord, the Moon; ſhe has an Intrigue with my Body, and never puts on new Cloaths, but at my Coſt: ſhe means to be very fine about Thurſday come ſevennight▪ that is to ſay, in the Full; and then the World will ſee if my bankrupt Body be able to carry on ſuch a Trade.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: All's one, Sir, if you were dead, Malice wou'd live and entertain Cenſure.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well Sweet heart, as long as I don't entertain it, you need not troubled.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I confeſs, if I have the comfort of your Love—

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: You have, you have, Woman; don't make more fiddle faddle then needs, and hinder us from buſineſs of conſequence.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, no body takes a Degreein my Univerſity, but they perform their Exerciſes, which you two have done, I have had experience of your Vertues, and pronounce you both innocent. All the Shame and Grief is mine, that my only Son, the Pillar of my Family is crack'd or rotten, mad or a Knave: I ſay he is mad.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I ſay he is a ſuborn'd Raſcal:

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I'm o' the Doctors mind.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'le give you an unanſwerable reaſon to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I never diſcover'd it, not ſo much as in the Boys Face, and I'le ſee through ſuch a Boy as he, as plain as through a new-laid Fgg. The oldeſt Face shall no more cheat me, than old Coin does an Antiquary.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And what am I? an Owl.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I don't ſay you are.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: You two will kindle again.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: No, the Boy shall decide the diff'rence, I ha' ſent for him; here he comes.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: This Woman is a Whore, and I was in the right.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What ſay you now? does not the Madman peep through all his Looks and Geſtures?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'le examine him—Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hold your prating—damn'd Whore.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: De'e ſee? ſtark mad.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Who ſubborn'd you to accuſe your Mother of bei • ng Proſtitute to Florio?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Who ſubborn'd you to accuſe the Title of Doctor of Divinity, of being a Proſtitute to ſuch an ignorant Aſs?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sirrah, I am a Scholar, and you are an ignorant, ſawcy, pragmattical Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, if Rogue and Raſcal be Latin and Greek, thou art the beſt Scholar in Chriſtendom, for no Man living is ſo ver •• in thoſe Languages.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: When I uſe thoſe Languages, I, like Adam, give every Beaſt 〈◊〉 proper Name.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And when I call thee ignorant Coxcom •• , I give thee no other Name then thy own Sermons do. That thou art an inſolent Fool, is the only true Doctrine thou preacheſt.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Is he mad, or no?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: He is more Knave, than • ool, Sarrah, don't you abuſe the D •• tor.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: How do I know 〈◊〉 a Doctor, we have only his word for it, nor that neither when he Preaches.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'le hang you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, thou art a Doctor at that.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Ay, and of Divinity too, you impudent Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Where did you take your Degree in, Beargarden?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: In a learn'd Univerſity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
I, the Univerſity of Coffee-houſes, the Univerſity of Lies, where, if any one ſpeakes Truth, the Univerſity 〈◊〉
it's Charter. • here thou'rt a Doctor, and the Bricklayer principal Fellow of a Colledge.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Don't you meddle wi' me, you malapert boy you, the greateſt Lords and Politicians of the Kingdom, of our Party, won't be ſo ſawcy wi' meas you are, but Court me, and are proud o' me, and depend upon my Counſel and Countenance.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Depend on thy Countenance! They hav •
〈◊〉 dependance— damn'd confounded Woman? great with a Raſcal [Aſide. Gnaw'd with Diſeaſes, 'till he's as enomous as a chaw'd • ullet▪ and refuſe me—Jilt▪ I'le make her great with me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
You ſee what Sa •• eys of madneſs he has of Craffy! but to what purpoſe ſhou'd I ſpeak to him? Craffy, if you have any
underſtanding; ſay whether you ſaw your Mother in the Garden houſe wi' Florio, or not?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why I will ſwear that—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Look upon her.
