sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: She's the handſom'ſt Woman in the World, what Breaſts ſhe has!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: The handſom'ſt Woman? what's that to the buſineſs? Is not this diſtraction, Gentlemen? Anſwer to the queſtion, did you ſee her in the Garden-houſe with Florio?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'le ſee her there with me, or I'le— [Aſide. Hark you, Gentlewoman, you know I ſaw you there; I have three Witneſſes to ſwear it; meet me there, I'le bring you oft.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Your Witneſſes are perjur'd Raſcals, and you are an Aſs, who abuſe me juſt now I'm coming to have more inclination for you, than my Conſcience will admit of.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo— [Aſide. I did not ſee her there, I did not.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Then thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Will you meet me there?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Perhaps I may, if you'l be civil.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Delicate Rogue.

div.p: Now I ſwear I did not ſee her there, but that damn'd Raſcal I did ſee there; an impudent rotten Fellow, that has never a ſound bit about him, of his own, but is inlay'd like a Cabinet: that he ſhou'd dare to kiſs and embrace ſuch a delicate Woman as my Mother, there.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Why, did he?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Did he? ay, a hundred times, I ſaw him, a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: And yet juſt now, you ſaid ſhe was not there.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: How now? was I there?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I forget my ſelf—(Aſide.) No faith ſhe was not there.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How cou'd he embrace her then?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: In his fancy, I ſaw her in his Fancy, as plain as cou'd be, he has a huge fancy for her.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Fancy, Lord help thee Boy, thou haſt ſtrange fancies; take himaway, he's a ſad 〈◊〉 —take him away, or he'l break my heart. Lock him up.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Lockme up? how ſhall I come at my Mother then? Pox take it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He's far gone.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I think my Judgment is to be rely'd upon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wiſh in his madneſs he had not torn my good Reputation, the only Image of a Man we ought to venerate.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I wou'd have no body's Picture preſerv'd but the Doctors.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nor I. Well, I have news to tell you from another World, the very Devils have more care of us, than our pretended Friends. A Spirit appear'd to a Country Maid, and told her, Naples wou'd be burnt on this Night, if care was not taken.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! where is the Maid?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In the Country, she was coming to Town, fell ill by the way, ſo she has ſent the Story to the Viceroy, by the Poſt.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: And what ſays he?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He laughs at it.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He's a fine Fellow.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: He's in the right, why the Devil wou'd not the Spirit come Poſt himſelf, but deliver a Meſſage of this conſequence to a ſilly Country Goſſip? The Devil never imployes any but Fopps of Spirits, he's not fit to be a Devil, I'le juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: How do you know 'twas a Devil? May be 'twas the Soul of ſome of our Friends.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Let it be whoſe Soul it will, I ſay the Soul was a Fop. I think People, when they are dead turn Tonies; they never ſay one wiſe word, nor ever come into any wiſe Company.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: The Viceroy is a pure Canary-Bird, I'le have him turn'd out of his place, I'le prove he is a Mahometan, he was Circumciſed at Bar—bar—badoes.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I believe you mean Barbary, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Why, ay, Barbadoes is the Latin name for Barbary. I love to ſwear like a Scholar, and a Doctor, as I am.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Well, I'le go put all the Town in Arms.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'le go wi' you, I dare not ſtay in any Houſe

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I dare not ſtir out o' mine.

div.stage: Enter a Servant conducting Pietro, who is diſguis'd like a Spanyard o'Quality.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
My Lord, here is a Great Gentleman lays he muſt n • eds
ſpeak with your Lordſhip preſently, about affairs that concern your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Look to me, for I know not what he is.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: My Lord, I muſt beg leave to whiſper you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
You may, Sir, but I muſt alſo beg leave to uſe 〈◊〉
theſe are dangerous times▪ ſome men ha' been almoſt whiſper'd out o' their Necks.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
I come from the Viceroy; he is ſenſible of your great Parts and Intere •• , and deſires to ſpeak wi' you preſently; and if you will be his • riend, he offers you your own tearms, 〈◊〉
Honour, Profit, and Greatneſs.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Had is it come to this? I like this—Sir, 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
A Chair waits for you at the door; he deſires 〈…〉
may be manag'd with all ſecrecy 'till 'tis ſettled.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I will 〈…〉 a Wiſe Man. Mr. Florie I'm call'd away about matters of very great Importance, I muſt take my leave.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: O' this 〈…〉 Night, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: It muſt be.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
Wou'd 〈◊〉 Nation were ſetled once, that we might en
•• y one another.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: It may 〈…〉 ſpeedily. Good Night.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Good Night • Madam.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: 〈…〉 Mr. Florio! are you well enough?

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.p:
〈…〉 , my Lord, my good Name is the Child of a
•• ck Man. ſeldom ſound, never thought to be ſo. I muſt be
• ender of it: Good Night, Madam; come, my Lord, I'le ſee you in your Chair.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: No, no, I cannot ſtay for your dreaming pace: I'm in haſte.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay, I cannot ſtay; good Night, good Night.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, how greedily this Fool ſwallows the 〈◊〉 ,
• s the room, that muſt paſs with him for the Court, and ſecure him till his Horns be grown, ſo dreſt • e cannot know it to be one in his own Houſe?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: That was my care.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You ſee my Man's new furniture has cheated him.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So ſhall the Room.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then we may ſecurely hoiſe Sail for 〈…〉 . All the Mudd that barr'd it up, we have con • eyed away, and I will come a Shore on theſe white Cliffs, and plant my Heart there for ever.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Do ſo, and I'le promiſe thee the Happineſs and Wealth I gain by the Reſidence of my Prince, ſhall not make 〈◊〉 ungratefully Factious. 〈◊〉 true to me, and I'le be moſt Loyal to thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then we'll be the happieſt pair in the whole World.

div.head: SCENE Changes.
div.stage: Enter Pietro conducting the Podeſta with Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: My Lord, you are very welcome to Court.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Take not your private Reception ill, for f • w or none are entruſted with this • ntrigue; 'tis a great State 〈◊〉 and great Honours, to my knowledge, are deſigned you, no leſs than the High 〈◊〉 of Lord Treaſurer.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Lord Treaſurer?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Sir, I ſpeak what I know; 'twill be ſome time before you come to it; and the Viceroy will expect you ſacrifice to him the Doctor, Bricklayer, Florio—.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay, and my Father too, if he were alive, he ſhou'd hang 'em all. Lord Treaſurer!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, you won't 〈◊〉 ſome Oaths—and—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Nothing, I'le refuſe nothing, Sir, for ſuch Honour as this: Lord Treaſurer!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: I'le acquaint his Highneſs with your Arrival: you muſt be willing to ſuffer ſome attendance, the common affliction of all Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'le do, or ſuffer any thing, for ſo much Glory as this. Lord Treaſurer!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant, Sir: Lord Treaſurer! to what Grandeur am I riſing? Some of the Court are coming.

div.stage: A noiſe of picking the Lock, and Enter Craffy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So, I ha' got out o' my Priſon.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Craffy in Court!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So, I have ſhut back the Lock admirably, and got out of Priſon: my Father! but why ſhou'd I be afraid of him? he thinks me mad, and will be afraid o' me.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What a notable Boy is this? I thought he was mad, and he has more Wit than my ſelf, h'as climb'd to preferment before me; I always ſaid this Boy had nimble parts. Son.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You are ſurpriz'd to ſee me in Court.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: In Court!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I am as much ſurpriz'd to ſee your Wit, which ſo ſubtilly diſguis'd your Policy under pretended madneſs.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Policy! am I grown from a Madman to a Politician?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Well, I am proud o' thee. Father and Son, both Favourites! o' my word we ſhall be a great Family. Well—what ſays the Viceroy to thee o' me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Viceroy!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay, and how art thou in with the Vice-Queen?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Vice-Queen!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ay, for Women have great power in all Courts. Did'ſt now come out of the Vice-Queen's ſide?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Out of her ſide!

sp.speaker: Pod.
Cra.
sp.p: My dirty hole, the Vice-Queens Apartment!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Why art ſo ſhy to thy Brother Courtier? I'm thy Brother Courtier now.

sp.speaker: Cra.
Pod.
sp.p: Thou art cloſe wi' me, but I'le be open with thee: I have ſold all the Whigs, and my ſelf into the Bargain; and what doſt think the Court gave me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: The Lord Treaſurer's place; I am to be Lord Treaſurer. Boy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Child.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: The Lord bleſs thee, and deliver thee from Poetry, for thou art a ſad ſight.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ha! a noiſe! the Court aſſaulted! I am cruel affraid the Whigs ha' made ſome attempt upon the Court, and got the better, then will they catch me in Court, and hang me for a Turn-coat.—hide Boy, hide.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yet cannot I tell which of us is mad, or where I am.

div.stage: Enter Governour, a Guard, Doctor and Bricklayer Priſoners▪ Porter of the Podeſta's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Friend, you were beſt confeſs where your Lord is, before I break open any more Doors, for if I find him in the Houſe, after your denial of him, I ſhall puniſh you.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Indeed, if it pleaſe your Highneſs, he never came home ſince he went abroad with a ſtrange Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Your Lady you ſay's a Bed, and will not be diſturb'd?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I muſt diſturb her, if it be your pleaſure, but ſhe has forbid any Perſon coming near her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: The Governour o'th' City here? then the Whigs are worſted, and I'le ſhew my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: The Governour here! then this is the Court.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: De'e ſee, Sirrah? your Maſter's in the Firſt Room I come in.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I did not know it, indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Secure the Podeſta.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Secure me!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ay, the Viceroy will endure your intollerable diſorders no longer. Arm the City at mid-night, and ſend your Agitators abroad to diſperſe new minted lies among 'em, the Com wherewith you pay all your Forces. I have order to ſecure you all.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: 〈…〉 and my Habeas Corpus.
How now brother, Courtier! is this your greatneſs

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Ha! am I trapann'd? was this fair o'th Viceroy to entice me to Court with promiſes of Honours and Preferments, and then ſecure me?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The Viceroy entice you to Court with Promiſes?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Yes, you had not ſeen me in Court elſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, when did I ſee you in Court?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: When! that's a ſtrange Queſtion. Where am I now▪

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That's a ſtranger Queſtion. Do you not know where you are? do you not know your own home?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My own home! why am I at home?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The man's mad.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Then the diſputes at an end? my Lord, I beg to 〈◊〉
his Guardian.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: If I be at home, I have had a fine trick plaid me and by this Gentleman, I am glad I have you Sir pray let him be ſecur'd, and examin'd Sir, where am I?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: At home Sir.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p:
At home! and wherefore did you entice me out o •
my houſe, and after you had danc'd me to and fro, 〈◊〉
me home again, pretending you brought me to Court.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Confeſs. Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: His Periwig. and falſe Beard, confeſs 'twas that his Maſter might make my Lord Treaſurer a Cuckold— for this is Florio's man—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Florio's man! then his Maſter is an Impoſtor, my Wife a Slut, and I'm a Fool.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And a Knave, for I believe you went abroad with deſigns to betray us.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I ſhan't inform you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: There's not an honeſt man in the world.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Now am I to be believ'd, or no? Sirrah you Pimp, where ha' you pimp'd this couple together?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: In the next room.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Force open the door.

div.stage:
[The Scene is drawn, Florio and Roſaur •
are diſcover'd ſitting Arm in Arm, they offer to fly, and are catch'd.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You Villain—[draws]

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Diſarm the fellow.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: You Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You Jilt.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Tory in Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Are you ſick Sir? I'le know the ſtate of your body.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: My wife can tell.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: There's another Lady ſhall enquire a Rack.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That Lady's a ſcurvy bedfellow, I'le ſpare her pains.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Are you to dye a Thurſday come-ſennight?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I believe 'twill be put off a little longer now.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So, you are a healthy Raſcal, are you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why truly I find my ſelf very finely well, I thank heaven, very well.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh you ſhamming Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Ro • .
sp.p: How! ha' you abus'd mee thus? and are you an Impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: And wou'd you abuſe us, Madam? and cheat us into a belief you did not know it?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Do you believe I did?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Did not all our eyes ſee you Arm in Arm?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What o' that? I invoke heaven to witneſs—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Away you Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Is it poſſible—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Never come near my bed, or ſight more.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I invoke heaven to witneſs—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: That thou ſhalt never come near my bed, or ſight more.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh Impudences!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: The impudence is yours. I modeſtly conceal'd your ſhame and mine, and you would force me impudently to confeſs.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Is it my ſhame that you are a Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe is a true Whig, and has revolted from you, becauſe you did not pay her nightly Penſion well.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I hope you have Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wonnot ſay whether I have, or no.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: But I will ſay thou art a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I'me an honeſter man than your ſelf, and truer to my Principles, you wou'd have left 'em for Preferment. I
retain 'em, our Principles are, he is not to be regarded who has a right to Govern, but he who can beſt ſerve the ends of Government▪ I can better ſerve the ends of your Lady▪ than you can, ſo I lay claim to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Reſ.
sp.p: And you have my conſent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
So, I have the voice o • the Subject too; then you are m •
wife, and I'le keep you.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Oh brave! Sir, muſt this be?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ask the Law, I muſt do all things according to Law.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your Servant, My Lord Treaſurer; theſe are a fine Crew, Sir, Here's the Bricklayer, Sir, a fine Privy Counſellor, is he not? he expects alſo every day to be a Colonel, he is already a Colonel Preſumptive.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Here's the Doctor too, a fine Divine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Si • rah don't meddle with me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He applies himſelf very much to the Bible, I mean to kiſs it. He Prays much, ſo help him the Contents o'th' Book, and they have helped him to many a pound, though they and he ſcarce ever ſaw one another. The Bible is the only Benefice he has, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Si • rah, I'le have your Ears.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Never when you Preach, Doctor. They are all very good Men, never take Heavens Name in vain, that is, Swear, and get nothing by it; but to get your Eſtate, or command, they'l Swear your Head off.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That I believe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
They are moderate Drinkers o' Wine, but will Carrouſ •
Water abundantly, for they'l drink your Rivers, Fiſh and all, and put your Land into it for a Toaſt, if you'l let 'em. And yet ſometimes they have very narrow Swallows, they cannot down with a little Church Ceremony, but they'l ſwallow Church Lands, Hedges and Ditches.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, my Lord Pedeſta, your Office the Victroy and the Council will order be manag'd by a wiſer Man.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I wonnot part wi' my Office but by Law. I have done nothing but by the Advice of Able Council—Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That Knave.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Counſellor Bartoline, will our Charter juſtifie us?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: In What? keeping a Bawdy houſh? your Houſh ha • li been made a Bawdy-houſh, notch by me, but by Florio, your ſhicke ſhaint—a yam'd Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I know it to my ſorrow. But the Queſtion I ask is, will our Charter juſtifie our Arming without the Viceroy's leave?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have chold you it will a hundred chymſh, and let the Viſhroy do hiſh worſht.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: • ow! bring that Knave to me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir, the Governour ot'h City commands you to come to him

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The Governour here • od' ſhame, yen l'me ruined, I'me ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Sir, did not the Viceroy retain you for his Lawyer, and did not you ſend him the direct contrary Opinion?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yeſh and pleaſh your Lordſhip, and I ſent his Highneſh chrue Law. I only ſheatcher'd Chaſ among theſe Fellowſh cho catch 'em, cauſh I found 'em arrant Raſhcalſh, and cho ſhew my Loyalchy, I have drawn up Arti • lsh of High Chreaſon againſt 'em, and you may hang 'em all.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What a Rogue's here?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: This was you that underſtood Mankind.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: I'l • never pretend to it more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: There yey are Shir—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Articles of High Treaſon, with other High Crimes and Miſdemeanours againſt Don Pedro, Duke of Oſſuna, Viceroy of Naples: How! Articles of Treaſon againſt the Viceroy?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh, My Lord, My Lord, I ha' given you the wrong Paper, yat wash a Paper I drew to delude yesh Rogush. Pray dont chake advanchage of an old fumbling Fellow.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: An old Blood-hound.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I beg you Lordships pardon on my kneesh.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, if the Viceroy were at a Bar, you'd bring him upon his Knees.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Ingeed I am Loyal Shir. I have diſcover'd a horrible
Plotch, one Flor • o has Plotched cho open the Gatesh, and letch in the French.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: G •• .
sp.p: What▪ Florio▪

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
A de • aush'd Fellow, yat prechends to be Sinck, 〈◊〉
Godly, Preachesh up and down for a Benefish. Yat ish 〈◊〉
Mansh Wife he likesh.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Here's the Man you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Then I deſire he may be apprehenged for High 〈…〉
I have choo Witneshesh will Shwear all yish upon 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: what means the Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yesh are the Men.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What C • untry-Men are they?

sp.speaker: 1. Wit.
sp.p: I am an Iriſh man, I'me not asham'd o' my Country

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: 1 Wit.
sp.p:
Hubbubbow! ask an Iriſh Man what Religion he 〈◊〉
ſhertainly it I be an Iriſh Man, I'me a good Catholick

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, and what can you Swear againſt Florio •

sp.speaker: 1. Wit.
sp.p:
I'le Shwear heſh a Knave and a Raſcal, and a 〈◊〉
and haſh been in a Plot.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What Plot?

sp.speaker: 1. Wit.
sp.p: To kill all the Town, and let in the French; yeſh indeed.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Kill all the Town by my ſelf.

sp.speaker: 1 Wit.
sp.p: No, I waſh to have a touſh and Cobs to help tee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Cobs! what are thoſe?

sp.speaker: 1. Wit.
sp.p: Pieſhes of Eight—and I waſh to have ten hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To let in the French, and make a Fire in the Town, and cut all our Troa • ſh; yeſh indeed.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: All our troatſh? waſt thou to cut thy own throat.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sir, we wo • 't have our Evidence ba • led—he means All our throats—doſt not?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Yesh indeed—all our throatsh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'le ſwear I never ſaw this Fellows face before in my life.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Hubbubbow, tou hasht drunk above a touſand times ushqaebagh wi'me, to de carrying on of tish plot.

sp.speaker: F • o.
sp.p: Ushquebagh! what's that?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
A brave Liquor tat we have in Ireland, tersh no
ſuch here, I never shaw any here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How cou'd I drink 〈◊〉 then?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I don't know how tou coud'ſt drink it, but tou hash drunk it above a toushand times, and a toushand.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Come, come Sirrah, I doubt you are a Vill • in.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
Hubbubbow! tou talk'ſt like an Engliſh 〈…〉 , wilt tou be an English Heretique, and not believe 〈◊〉
Irishman.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Come, come, the Fellow's an honeſt ſimple Fellow

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ay, by Shaint Patrick am I.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: H'as diſcover'd a horrible plot, only wants expreſſion. Is it poſſible you Rogue you? was this the meaning of all your canting, and deluding us, to lull us aſleep whilſt our Throats are cut?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Thou Monſter • not only Cuckold me, but Cut my Throat.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 〈…〉 ſay the • ellow before.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I'le Swear, I have ſeen him with thee above • orty times.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And ſo have I too I'le teach the Rogue to ly with my Miſtriſs, I'le hang him if I can.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: So the Plot's prov'd, plainly prov'd.
A Plot to murder me • s prov'd, but ſure ſuch a Ra • cal as this who has ſworn Contradictions shall not be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: He is a Rogue, and a Traytor that does not behave every Word he ſays.

div.stage: Enter the Clerk and Officers, with Artal and Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, I have catch'd Mr. Florio here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What Florio? art out of thy Wi • sh▪

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: The Florio, that was to let in the Fren •• , and run away with my Miſtriſs, • ha' catch'd 'em together, and brought 'em

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Thou art Mad, our Evigensh has shworn again ••• a noyer Man.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then your Evidence is Mad, and don't know what they Swear.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
Sir, I know what I Swear as well as you do, and know Mr. Florio as well as any Man, I have known him this ſeven
years, and know this Man to be the true Florio, and a Traytor that plotted to let in the French.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then thou art a Raſcal, and bought off, for this is the true Florio, and the Traytor that plotted to let in the French.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Then thou art a Raſcal, and hired to be one; for I, and all the Town can ſwear his Name is Artal.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh, the Devil! all our Plot's confounded.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You Iriſhman, which do you ſay is the true Florio?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tiſh ish de Man I wash bid to shwear againsht.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Bid to ſwear againſt? who bid you? confeſs, or the Rrack ſhall make you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh! preedee do not wrack me, and I will confeſs. Tiſh Knave and I had shome acquaintansh, and sho I had shome occaſionsh for Money, and I borrow'd shome of him, and he had shome occashionsh for Teshtimony, and sho I tought I wash oblig'd in shivility to lend him shome Teshtimony, and sho he bed meshwear againsht one Florio, and shaid tish was de Man, but if • ou wilt forgive me, I'le shwear him off again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So, Sirrah; and who put you upon this?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: An Attorney, Sir; employ'd, I ſuppoſe, by this Counſellor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O notorious mercinary Rogues! who'll believe ſuch Rogues as they are?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: None but Rogues.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Juſt now you ſaid he was a Rogue that wou'd not believe 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Ay, when they ſaid the ſame things that I did: what I ſaid was confirm'd by Craffy, a conſiderable young Man, Heir to a great Eſtate, and of a ſpotleſs Reputation, no Man can ſay the leaſt againſt him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And what ſay you, Craffy? ſpeak truth, if you mean to have any Fars.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.p: Or any part o' my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee this Iriſh-man with Florio?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I only ſpoke in a little Paſſion: I have ſome of the Doctors Infirmities, I'm paſſionate, and apt to ſwear in my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.p: Be perjur'd in a Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: This Fellow's the lyingſt Rogue in the Nation, and has been ſo from his Cradle.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Juſt now you ſaid no Man cou'd ſay the leaſt againſt him.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Sham upon Sham.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le clear all. This young Woman is my Kinſwoman, I hearing she was Married to that Old Man, brought to Town, and lodg'd in Houſe which Florio frequented; she not knowi • g me, I took upon me Florio's Name, and made addreſſes to her; partly to divertiſe my ſelf, but chie • ly to make tryal of her Vertue. The Old Man catch'd me in the act of Courtship, grew Jealous, and wou'd have abus'd his Wife, which, to prevent, I took her from him, he, to be reveng'd, hir'd Witneſſes to hang me for Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'le shwear he shpoke Creashon, but 'tish to no purpoſe, for now 'twil appear Malish.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: To Priſon with 'em all.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I beg your Lordship to intercede with the Viceroy for the Old Man, for my Couſins ſake, and command him to uſe her kindly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I shall conſider of it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I hanke your Lordship, but my Heartsh broken.

sp.speaker: Bai.
sp.p: Hang me, if you will: I'le ſwear I'm murder'd by Sulborners and Shamplotters.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And Traytorly Rogues.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Doctor, thou wilt give Titles in the laſt day of the Reign.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The laſt day it shall be. The Viceroy, and all of us will put an end to his Abſolute Negative Voice, his great power of degrading Lords and Dukes, into Rogues and Raſcals, if they will not purchaſe of him the Confirmation of their Titles, by capping to him: Nay, of depoſing Kings, if they ſlight his Councils. We will alſo Diſſolve all his Privy-Council: And ſo Gentlemen, henceforward be wiſe, leave off the new Trade you have taken up, of managing State Affairs, and betake your ſelves to the Callings you were bred too, and underſtand. Be honeſt, meddle not with other Mens, matters eſpecially with Government, 'tis none of your Right. In short, trouble not your ſelves more than needs.
sp.l: Chiefly you Married Men, for all allow
You Married Men, have private Plagues enow.

div.head: The EPILOGUE 〈…〉 LEE in the Character of Bartoline the Old Lawyer▪

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: SIR, I come to you 〈…〉 worthy Gentlemen, the World is pleaſed to call Wh •

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Whigs Sir, they are the Props and Pillars of the Nation.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Sir, There is a Poet has been ſo bold as to write a Play againſt 'em, in which ſeveral of 'em think themſelves abuſed; now, Sir, they deſire to know if they have not an Action of Slander againſt the Poet?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, ho's a Raico • l.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: And may not have conſiderable Damages?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh! very conſiderable—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Here are two Pieces.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Two Pieces—? pretty indifferent damages—I believe they may have ſome Dammages.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Here's one great perſon thinks himſelf much abus'd, and has ſent you 20 Pieces.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, he ſhall have great Damages, he ſhall trounce the Poet, a Raſcal to abuſe great perſons.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I'le tell him—Ex.
Sir, I come to you from a perſon that wants your Councel, but he is a ſwingeing Tory.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well, he's ne're the worſe man, provided he has a ſwingeing Purſe.

Sir, he has writ a Play againſt Faction • and ſome
• higs think themſelves hit home in it, and they are bringing Actions of Slander agai • ſt him to puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, if he has his the Whigs home, he is a good Ma • ks-man, for now they are all upon the Wing.
Sir, he deſires to know whether there lies an Action of Slander againſt hi • or no? and ſo, whether he had beſt compound the buſineſs in time, or go through with it?

sp.speaker: B • r.
sp.p: Oh! let him go through with it.
And you will aſſiſt him?

sp.speaker: B • r.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in private.
But he has no Money, he muſt Sue in Forma Pauperis.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Forma Pauperis? Oh! damn'd Rogue, does he abuſe Great Men, a • d has he no Money? Tell him have conſider'd it, and I
〈◊〉 defend a ſlanderous Raſcal in abuſing honeſt men.
You ſaid you would help him through with it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, through the Pillory. A Raſcal without Money abuſe Great Men, and then Sue in Forma Pauperis!— Come the Court is fat—I muſt Plead for the Plaintiff.

div.l: From WHIGS▪ to whom by Cuſtom it belongs,
WHIGS are all Freeholders of their Tongues,
And 〈◊〉 too—
I' le prove it out of Janeway's Reports,
And the Decrees of ſev'ral Coffee Courts.
The POET has no title then to rail,
Let him be ſeiz'd, nor let Wit be his Bayl,
Wit is a Tory, ne're with us would joyn,
Wit never help'd the Whigs to write one Line.
'T has been • ccus'd, and in our Writings ſought
But ſtill the Co • oner Non inventus brought:
But Learned Judges, I leave all to you,
If you're for TORIES, I w • ll be ſo too.
Noint Witches, they will fly, though ne're ſo old;
I'le be as nimble too, • oint me with Gold:
I'le quickly to the Tory Party skip,
Greaze my Fiſt well, I'le let cur Faction ſlip.
